March 25, 1938.

Department of Mines & Natural Resources,
Welfare & Training Service,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attention Mr. Philip Phelan

Dear Sirs:

Replying to your communication of March 15th requesting railway company's receipts for the freight charges shown upon our invoices of February 23rd, #4565, and February 25rd, #4566.

First of all let us advise that it is absolutely impossible for us to forward such railway company's freight receipts to you for the reason that when we tendered upon your requisition 18657, file 1558, our computation of freight was based upon inclusion of this merchandise in our carload shipments to our Edmonton branch and L.C.I.L shipment from Edmonton to Grouard. Undoubtedly our quotation was favourable in comparison with other quotations and resulted in your order #2640 being forwarded to us February 3rd, and your purchase order exactly copied the figures of our quotation, which showed the sales tax and freight as separate items. Were it not for the fact that the merchandise could have been enclosed in a carload shipment to Edmonton, freight charges would necessarily have been higher upon our quotation, but the facts as they are simply make it impossible for us to submit receipted railway freight bills for these amounts.

Yours very truly,

PARKHILL BEDDING LIMITED

[Signature]

Secretary-Treasurer

That, as these buildings are Church owned, new works, repairs and purchase of equipment constitute a grant and, therefore, the approval of Your Excellency in Council is desirable.

The Minister, therefore, recommends that approval be given for the expenditure at the above-mentioned Indian Residential Schools of the sum of $34,582.00, same to be chargeable to Vote Number 169, 1938-39, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

R. J. Lemaire,
Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Honourable,
the Minister of Mines & Resources.

I hope that the misunderstanding which occurred this year will not interfere with the work. I have done by best to cope with the situation.

I wonder if I should not point out the terrible situation developing in this part of Alberta. Hunting has been very poor for the last season, and there is no hope that fur will be restored for some time as, due to a prolonged drought, fire is sweeping the country. Fire extends from here to down North Fort-Vermilion and over. It is fortunate that we are doing some work in our Missions. Otherwise, most of the families would be starving. And what will happen next winter?... having this in view, we use as much as possible Indian work.

I will consider a duty to provide with any further explanations or details asked for.

Believe me, Dear Sir,

Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your No. 131-1-5 of the 7th ultimo, re letter addressed to the Department by Rev. J. Flourde, O.M.I., in which he refers to a letter received from Rev. P. S. Lajoie, O.M.I., Administrator for the R. C. Schools in the Grouard district, stating that on account of drought during the past summer, the school gardens did not produce sufficient vegetables for their needs, and that it will therefore be necessary to ship in a certain amount of canned vegetables.

Upon receipt of your letter, I wrote our Indian Agent, Mr. N.P. L'Heureux, as follows:

"I am in receipt of a communication from the Supt. of Welfare and Training, stating that the Department have been informed that owing to the drought conditions that prevailed in the Grouard district, where we have several residential schools, even the school gardens did not produce vegetables in sufficient quantities, and that such vegetables as are considered essential for the health of the children will have to be imported, at great cost, due to transportation charges.

Will you please discuss this matter with Rev. Father Lajoie, Administrator of the R. C. Schools in the Grouard district, and let me have your report and recommendation in the matter.

Also, let me have similar reports regarding the Anglican Schools at Whitefish and Wabasca."

I have since visited the Lesser Slave Lake Agency, being there from November 28th to December 6th. On my arrival there, Agent L'Heureux informed me he had written to the Principals of all Schools, asking them for a report of what they had harvested this year. He had received replies from all but Rev. Cathcart of St. Andrew's C. E. School at Whitefish Lake, who was away on a holiday.

Agent L'Heureux had not discussed the matter with Rev. P. S. Lajoie. This we did together, when he informed us that they were short of canned vegetables at all schools, and asked that we recommend purchase of same by the Department as per lists attached hereto.

The Agent and I then visited the Grouard, Sturgeon Lake and Joussard Schools, saw the stores of vegetables -- canned and bulk -- which they had on hand, and are agreed and satisfied that these are not sufficient to last until next year's crop is ready for use.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
O T T A W A .

ATTENTION: Mr. R. A. Hoey.
We met Rev. Father Beuglet, Principal of Wabasca R.C. School and found that his school was the hardest hit by drought, his potato crop having been a failure. He claims that the few potatoes harvested will not be fit for seed; they are spoiling. Twenty-five sacks have been thrown away already.

We did not visit Fort Vermilion School, but Father Lajoie stated he had been there this Autumn and found they did not have sufficient of certain vegetables.

We visited the Church of England School at Whitefish Lake. The Principal had not yet returned from his holiday. Mr. N. Reynolds, the Boys' Supervisor and farming Instructor, who was in charge, informed us they had sufficient vegetables for their requirements.

We did not visit the Wabasca Church of England School, but communicated by local radio and telegraph with Rev. C. N. Middleton, the Principal, who stated he will require 50 bushels of potatoes and 40 bushels of carrots.

The drought did great damage in the Grouard district—more so to small seed (garden stuff). Late rains helped grain (oat) crops, but did not benefit garden stuff, which had made a start and withered away before the rains came.

I recommend that the request for potatoes and canned goods be approved, purchase to be made from wholesale houses.

From personal observation and conversation with the Principals, I would say the other residential schools in the Province have sufficient vegetables for their requirements.

Rev. P. S. Lajoie told me that it was his intention to go East after Christmas, and that he would call on the Department when passing through Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

C. Pant. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Reverend Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of October 27 and my reply of November 7 in connection with drought conditions prevailing in the Grouard district of Alberta during the past summer.

A very complete report has been received from Mr. C. P. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies, and it appears that at some of the schools at least the school gardens did not produce sufficient vegetables to meet their requirements.

Our appropriation for the current fiscal year did not provide any funds that could be used to reimburse the schools for the loss that they have suffered. It might also be argued that conditions in the Grouard district are not similar to the conditions that prevailed last year in the Province of Saskatchewan when assistance was given to schools that had suffered from drought. The Province of Saskatchewan suffered from drought conditions for several years during which time no help had been given the schools and as a result their condition deserved special consideration last year. I understand that the summer of 1938 was the first time in many years that the Grouard district had suffered from drought.

Taking the above into consideration and the further fact that the Church representatives recently met the Honourable the Minister with a view to having the deduction in the per capita rate restored, I feel

Rev. J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
619 McDermot Avenue,
Winnipeg, Man.
that it would not be advisable to urge him to reimburse the schools in the Grouard district for a loss which, it is hoped, will not occur again.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Extract from Inspector Schmidt's report on Grouard Indian residential school visited on November 28, 1938.

WATER SUPPLY

INADEQUATE: A pipe-line from the school to Buffalo Bay (the extreme North-west end of Lesser Slave Lake) was used in the past. Owing to drought this summer, that part of the lake is now almost dry, except for a small body of water found on each side of a creek which runs through this bay. A ditch, several hundred feet long, was dug last summer, to bring the water from the creek to the end of the pipe-line. This, however, did not prove satisfactory, as the water therein was riled and weedy. I am attaching hereto a diagram showing the distance from the buildings to the water, at the present time. The pipe-line cannot now be used, as the shallow water in the lake and ditch is frozen through.

(Sgd.) C. P. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Grouard Indian Residential School
Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School
Joussard Indian Residential School
Vermilion Indian Residential School.

It is reported that the water situation at the four schools mentioned above is very serious and we have received an urgent request for an engineer to visit them at the earliest possible date with a view to determining what is the best action to take.

I should, therefore, appreciate it if you could send an engineer to these schools and have him report what should be done to secure an adequate supply of water at each of them. It is understood, of course, that he will include in his report not only an outline of the work but an estimate of the cost.

The Grouard school is located 13 miles from the village of Grouard, Alberta. The Joussard and Sturgeon Lake schools can be reached from Grouard. I would recommend that an engineer first proceed to Grouard and the Principal there will arrange for transportation to Joussard and Sturgeon Lake. If your engineer wires Rev. C. Fahler, O.M.I., Principal, Grouard Indian Residential School, Grouard, Alberta,
regarding the time of his arrival at Crouard Railway Station the Principal will arrange to have someone meet him and take him to the school.

The Vermilion residential school, near Fort Vermilion, can only be reached at this time of the year by plane. I understand that a plane for Fort Vermilion leaves Edmonton every Sunday night.

Director.

Dear Sir,

I have just received from His Excellency Mgr U. Langlois,
O.M.I., of Grouard, a report of the survey made by the Engineer sent
by the Department to investigate on the water problem at the Grouard
Indian Residential School.

According to the report, the Engineer recommends the
building of a large cistern where the water coming from the roofs
or pumped from the lake could be stored for winter use.

I have no explanations. It seems the most practical way,
and the least expensive too, to secure water. There is no doubt that
the project is approved by His Excellency Mgr Langlois since he asks
me to wire him the answer if the Department agrees to the proposition.
Due to mild weather and to the fact that there is practically no frost
in the ground, the work could be done this winter.

This cistern would be built with the credit asked for
on the fiscal year 1939-40. Some material will be needed, I presume
that the authorization of doing the work would mean that the material
can be bought locally, accounts to be rendered in due time and in due
form.

Would you, please, send me the answer at the following
address: 600 Cumberland Street, Ottawa, unless you wire yourself to
Mgr Langlois. Thanking you in advance for the attention.

I remain,

Dear Sir,

Yours truly,

Pf S. Lejoie, O.M.I.,
600 Cumberland,

I arrived at Croward Station at four a.m. this morning and was met by a team and sleigh and reached the mission at 7:30 a.m. Spent the day investigating and discussing the water supply situation here with various interested officials and feel that I should put on record my appreciation of the kindly courtesy and assistance I have received from all.

The present water situation is entirely unsatisfactory. For drinking water they are using melted ice obtained from the main Lesser Slave Lake, eight miles away. For domestic and sanitary purposes they are hauling water in barrels from the remnants of Buffalo Lake, a distance of 400 yards. For stock watering purposes they have a quite satisfactory well.

Buffalo Lake, which is now at its lowest recorded level, is, even at its best during high water periods, quite unsatisfactory in my opinion. It is simply a huge slough several square miles in extent when full but last summer was a big hay meadow. There is a small duneish creek formed by seepage, flowing through it from which they are now obtaining their domestic water supply. Today there was two feet of rusty-coloured water in the water-hole cut in the ice, which I am confident is likely to be subject to pollution and contamination. They have a pump for getting water out of this so-called lake, which is now out of action due to a complete absence of water at the intake. The pump would be useless in wintertime anyway due to the 2-inch water main freezing as it is only a couple of feet beneath the surface. Even during periods of high water, I believe this source for domestic water to be unsatisfactory.

The present well has a flow of approximately 1200 gallons (perhaps more) per day but I would condemn it as a source of domestic supply as it is too near the barn and in the barnyard and so subject to contamination from surface water. The water has a satisfactory taste and was also quite satisfactory for washing my hands in as the soap lathered well. However, the Sister in charge of the kitchen stated it was not satisfactory for laundry purposes and for washing the dishes as it required too much soap. She prefers to use melted snow water in winter and rain water in summer. While there may be something in what she says, I believe she has been doing it for so long that it has become a habit and would instinctively balk at any sudden change but might accept a change for the better slowly.
Recommendations

There is not only the well mentioned above but another well sixty feet from it used for stock watering purposes, both wells being about 33 feet deep. There have also been two other wells within two hundred yards getting water at the same level and I have been informed that there are some slight water seepages on Buffalo Lake shore in this close vicinity, all of which leads me to believe that there is a water-bearing strata about thirty to forty feet deep in the area occupied by the Mission Buildings.

Consequently, I would recommend that a well be dug (not drilled) on a site selected behind the Boys' Dormitory. I do not expect a big flow of water and so suggest that the well be about 6' x 8' to form a big collecting basin at the bottom. If a satisfactory supply is found, a pump should be installed with a 3000-gallon lumber tank built over it, from which water will flow by gravity to pressure tanks already installed in five buildings, namely Boys' Dormitory, Convent, Priests' House, Kitchen and Laundry. The gravity supply system would require to be buried about seven feet underground.

The above recommendation, if carried out, would I think provide all the main mission buildings with a satisfactory supply for drinking, ablutions, bathing, water closets and fair fire protection, and might in time be accepted by the Sisters for kitchen and laundry purposes.

The estimated cost is $1,700.00 but has been worked out roughly and is subject to change after I have had an opportunity of checking prices when passing through Edmonton.

There is one related question which I should mention and which will apply to any proposed work for the Mission Schools at Jeussard, Sturgeon Lake and Fort Vermillion. The current wages paid by all these schools for labour is low and a little more than half that set by the Fair Wages Scale. If our Engineering Branch does the work itself, it will have to pay the Fair Wages Scale which for labourers, for example, is 45¢ per hour while the local rate is 20¢ or 25¢ per hour. You can see where this would be upsetting locally. Consequently, I would suggest that any work done be turned over to the school authorities within the Indian Branch for execution, our Branch remaining entirely in an advisory capacity. This arrangement, I believe, would save the department money and be more satisfactory all around and especially to the local school authorities who are thoroughly conversant with local conditions and labour.

"G. K. LeCaplain"
Assistant Engineer.

P.S. Am going to Jeussard tomorrow (1st February) and afterwards to Sturgeon Lake by snowmobile if they can get it to work.

REPORT on Water Supply Situation at
Grouard Residential School, Alta.

The present water supply situation at this school is entirely unsatisfactory. For drinking water they are using melted ice obtained from the main Lesser Slave Lake eight miles away. For domestic and sanitary purposes they are hauling water in barrels from the remnants of Buffalo Lake, a distance of 400 yards. For stock-watering purposes, they have two satisfactory wells at the barns.

The sanitary and plumbing facilities within the school buildings are the best of the four residential schools that I visited during this trip, namely Grouard, Jouxard, Sturgeon Lake and Fort Vermilion, and would be adequate for the present situation if they had a proper source of water supply.

Buffalo Lake, which is now at its lowest recorded level, is, even at its best during high water periods, quite unsatisfactory as a source of water supply in my opinion. It is simply a huge shallow slough several square miles in extent when full, but last summer was practically dry except a big hay meadow. There is a small sluggish creek formed by seepage flowing through it, from which they are now obtaining their domestic water supply. On the 31st January, 1939, there were two feet of rusty-coloured water in the waterhole cut in the ice which I am confident is likely to be subject to pollution and contamination.

They have a pump for getting water out of this so-called lake, which is now out of action due to a complete absence of water at the intake. The pump would be useless in winter time anyway due to the 2" water main freezing as it is only a couple of feet beneath the surface. Even during periods of high water, I believe Buffalo Lake to be unsatisfactory as a source of domestic water supply.

The main well at the barn has a flow of approximately 1200 gallons per day. The other well close at hand has a much smaller flow. I would condemn both these wells as sources of domestic water supply owing to their proximity to the barn and the danger of their being contaminated by surface water. The water

...........
has a satisfactory taste and was also quite satisfactory for washing my hands in as the soap lathered well. However, the Sister in charge of the kitchen and laundry stated it was not satisfactory for laundry purposes nor for washing the dishes as it required too much soap. She prefers to use melted snowwater in winter and rainwater in summer. While this opinion can be appreciated as there is no softer water obtainable anywhere, still she may accept and use similar water to that obtained in the well at the barn if it can be obtained cheaper and more economically and with no more effort on her part than by turning on a faucet.

Both wells near the barns are about thirty-three (33) feet deep and have about five (5) feet of water standing in them. Two other wells have been dug in the past but are not now used; both had moderate flows of water. One of them outside the convent was 20 feet deep and the other between the priests' house and the lake shore was about 6 feet deep. I was informed that there are some slight water seepages along the shore of Buffalo Lake in the vicinity of the school buildings, all of which leads me to believe that there is a water-bearing stratum about 20 feet deep in the area occupied by the school buildings. Consequently, I think that sufficient water can be obtained from a well or wells for the school purposes, especially if a storage reservoir is built for banking up a supply of water on days when little is used for use when a larger quantity is required, such as on washdays and for fire protection purposes.

The residential buildings of the school are provided with water closets and septic tanks so the new well should be sited above the disposal fields and away from possible runoff water from the barns. With this in mind, I selected a site towards the rear of the boys' dormitory where they should try first for water. This site is on a slight eminence with the surface sloping away in practically all directions.

I would recommend that this well be dug 8 x 8 feet to form a collecting basin at the bottom and it is expected that water will be found within 40 feet. If a satisfactory supply is found, a pump should be installed with a 3000-gallon lumber tank built over it, from which water will flow by gravity to pressure tanks already installed in five buildings,- namely Boys' Dormitory, Convent, Priests' House, Kitchen and Laundry. The gravity supply system should be buried below frost line and the pump and 3000-gallon tank housed in a warm building.

The above recommendations, if carried out, would I think provide all the main school buildings with a satisfactory all-year supply of water for drinking, ablutions, bathing, water closets and fair fire protection (combined with chemical extinguishers), and might in time be accepted by the Sisters for kitchen and laundry purposes.

It is too early to discuss the details,
the engineer's report not being available yet. Nevertheless,
let me add a word concerning Grouard. We have had
the water coming in wells analysed at the Provincial Labora-
tory in Edmonton. This water has been classified as very
hard, so poor that we wonder if it would be advisable to
go in heavy expenses to secure such water. We feel that it
would be of good policy to inquire on the feasibility of
boring a well deep enough to get soft water. Soft water
has been encountered at 680 feet at McPhannan. This water
is used with satisfaction in Hospital and Hotel.
I am gathering data on the problem. Information secured will be communicated as soon as at hand. You easily understand that we are anxious to know how it will turn out.

Rest assured that we will do our best to profit by the cooperation the Department is willing to give us in the solution of one of the most important problems we are facing. We are awaiting for the recommendations of the Engineer to make the first move.

Thanking you once more for the interest you may to this question, I remain,

Dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.
Grouard, Alta.

On the recommendation of the engineer graciously sent by the Department to study the water problem at the Indian Residential School of Grouard, a sample of the water we can here from wells, surface wells, has been sent to the Provincial Laboratory for analysis. Dear Sir,

Re: Water Supply.

I take the liberty of inquiring if we can rely soon on the engineer's report and recommendations in connection with the water supply at the Indian Schools of the Vicariate of Grouard. By your letter of the 15th of March, I understood that this report was to be forwarded without delay. The mild season is so short here that we would like to start the work as soon as possible.

As pointed out in my letter of March 22nd, I have gathered data on the experiments made in the country. Water has been encountered nearly everywhere at different depths varying from 65 feet down. As to the nature of the water, I could not get any precise information as the boring was done for oil.

Having heard with great favour of Mr. Frederickson of St-Paul, Alta., the fellow who bore the well at the Indian School there, I wonder if it would not be profitable for us to call this gentleman here to study on the spot the best location for a well. Would you authorize the trip from St-Paul to here?.... We could have the benefit of his experience.

If there is no change in the temperature, the situation will be more serious next winter than during the past. There is very little water in the lake just now and it is receding every day. This water is far from being soft. We long for a change.

His Excellency Mgr U. Langlois, O.M.I., who is presently in the East, will presumably call on you in a few days. There is no doubt that a final decision on what is to be tempted will be arrived at.

Thanking you in advance, Dear Sir, for the attention you will give to this problem, I remain

Yours truly,

Could the Department provide me with plans and estimates for an Ice Barn?... I presume that the Department has plans for such building suitable for Indian Schools.

We have to do something in that line at Joussard. The Ice Barn is falling down. It has been question to get a Frigidaire for Joussard, but a keen study of the question has brought us to the conclusion that we don't dispose of the electric power requested for a frigidaire. We don't want to overload the batteries. We will have to stay with Ice Barns.

I am aware that at Resolution, N.W.T., they have a system of refrigeration by salt. This has been installed seven or eight years ago, at least. It may be that the plans have been provided by the Department. I would be interested to get information on this system.

Thanking you in advance for the attention you will give to this question,

I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours truly,

F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

DIRECTOR

Re: Grouard Indian Residential School
Jouassard Indian Residential School
Vermillion Indian Residential School
Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School

This week Right Reverend U. Langlois, O.M.I., Bishop of Grouard, visited this Branch and discussed with us the work that is in progress in connection with the water supply system at each of the above-mentioned schools.

As you have previously been informed funds were provided in the current year's appropriation for the improvements suggested by your engineers. However, it appears from the information received from Bishop Langlois that the work has not yet been completed.

No provision is being made in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41 for money required in connection with the water systems at these schools and moreover the Principal of each of the schools is anxious to secure a considerable amount of new equipment if funds available in the current year's appropriation are not being used in connection with the water systems.

The season is advancing and I am extremely anxious to know at the earliest possible date what progress has been made at each of the four schools mentioned above, also when the water systems at these schools will be completed.
I understand from the information contained in memoranda that you have submitted in connection with the above that all the materials required have been purchased.

I trust that you will find it possible to let me have, at the earliest possible date, a complete statement regarding the situation at each of these schools.

Director.

I desire to refer to my memorandum of November 22 in connection with the water supply system at each of the above-mentioned schools. I am today in receipt of the following letter from Rt. Rev. U. Langlois, Bishop of Grouard:

"Referring to our recent conversation about the water problem at our Indian Residential Schools I suggest that your Department hires the services of Mr. J. L. Cervais, of Montreal, to locate the exact spot where the wells should be drilled to assure a sufficient supply of water.

"Mr. Cervais is not what is commonly called a water wizzard; he is a real scientist, a radio-physic prospector of great experience who specialized in the finding of water and well drilling. As you know, the science of radiation has lately made immense progress and the success Mr. Cervais has met with proves that he has attained a high degree of proficiency in this new science. His address is 8609, St. Denis St., Montreal, and his phone No. Dupont 2965."
"May I mention that among the numerous credentials he would be glad to show you is a letter of recommendation to the Committee of National Defence signed by the Hon. Minister of Public Works, Mr. Cardin.

"I would suggest that Mr. Cervais be sent immediately to Joussard, Sturgeon Lake and other schools in Alberta or Saskatchewan where the water supply is not sufficient, and where your engineers have recommended the drilling of deep wells. In my humble opinion it is worth while trying the ability of this man, specially when his ability is so highly recommended. Mr. Cervais is not busy for the moment and he would be willing to undergo this trial almost for a nominal fee besides his expenses."

MEMORANDUM:

December 7, 1939.

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Water Supply Systems at Crouard, Joussard, Vermilion and Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential Schools.

I have your memorandum of the 24th ultimo with attached copy of a memorandum that you had received dated the 22nd ultimo from Dr. McGill with regard to the water supply systems at the above schools.

From recent reports received from Mr. Walker, we are now in a position to give the following information:

Crouard Water System:

The driller did not get water at the original depth estimated, and Mr. Walker advises that Father Lajoie has had the well continued to a greater depth in the hope of securing a suitable flow of water. On November 17th the well was down 650 feet with hopes that the drilling would soon break through shale formation into water bearing strata, particularly as water was found in a well drilled in the vicinity at approximately the above depth. Under the circumstances however, Mr. Walker in a letter to Father Lajoie, dated November 20th, authorized the continuing of the well to 800 feet, which is as deep as the driller can go with his machinery.

If, however, water is not found then, Mr. Walker has suggested to Father Lajoie that they drop back to the 330 foot level and arrange to utilize the flow of about three gallons a minute of water that was found at this latter depth. It is Mr. Walker's opinion that, while this water when encountered was muddy, that it will clear in time.

Mr. Walker is in the same position as this office when he states that he is not aware under what financial arrangement Father Lajoie has been able to extend the well so much deeper than originally estimated, but assumes that he has funds available for the purpose separate and additional to the original $1,700.00 allotment. Mr. Walker's statement of expenditure to date and estimated additional expenditure is as follows:

"Original allocation as per your letter of June 8th and as shown distributed in my report and letter of instructions of August 17th ...........................................$ 1,700.00

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,

The work done is as follows:

1. All distribution mains laid 7' underground and covered.

2. Well down 650 ft. At 330 ft., flow of approximately three gallons per minute topped. This was soft water but not clear. Father Lajoie has continued drilling and as he had reached 650 ft. before advising Mr. Walker, the latter instructed him to continue to the maximum depth capacity of the equipment on the ground, namely 800 ft., if necessary.

The work still to be done consists of completion of well drilling, the construction of a small pump house and the installation of the pressure tank and centrifugal pump.

Joussard Water System:

On the 20th ultimo Mr. Walker wrote Father Lajoie in accordance with instructions sent from this office based on authorization contained in your memorandum of the 14th ultimo for the undertaking of work at this school with $2,700.00 which Dr. McGill was arranging to provide.

Mr. Walker suggested to Father Lajoie that it would be advisable to get drilling of the Joussard well under way immediately, and to do this it would be necessary to get another rig for the job providing the driller he then had at Crouard was likely to be detained for some time.

Since writing Father Lajoie on the 20th ultimo, Mr. Walker has received no report. Therefore, as far as our information goes at the moment, the standing of this project is as follows:

"(A) Authorized Expenditure as per your letter of November 18th.................................. $2,700.00
Estimated additional funds required, based on all available information to date....... Nil.

(B) Work Done: No work done to date.

(C) Work to be done: Drill well near main building, install pressure tanks, make pipe connections and build pump house."
Fort Vermilion Water System:

Under date of October 20th last Mr. Walker received the following telegram from Father Huguerre:

"Well and cribbing down thirty two feet (Stop) Overcome by surface water coming fifteen hundred gallons per hour (Stop) Two twelve gallon buckets working steady with horses cannot keep up (Stop) No pump available here (Stop) Waiting your suggestions."

As the above depth would be below the water surface in the river, Mr. Walker considered that it was river water entering the well instead of surface water and on October 26th sent the following telegram to Father Huguerre:

"Retel do not dig well any deeper at present but extend cribbing to bottom of well (Stop) If possible complete trenching laying and connecting pipe install pressure tank complete wiring and erect pump platform chain hoist etc. (Stop) Advise soon as pump received and installed how high above bottom water rises in well before pumping."

The following is Mr. Walker's cost estimate and work statement:

"(A). Original allotment.................................$1,650.00
Estimated additional amount required.............350.00

Total estimated expenditure for season.......$2,000.00

(B). Work done.
Distribution mains installed in 7 ft. trenches, connections made and back filling completed. Well dug and cribbed. Pressure tank installed and connected.

(C). Work to be done.
1. Pump to be installed in cribbed well.
2. Trench to be dug and pipe to be laid from well to a point below water surface in river, providing seepage from river into well through river bank is inadequate and makes this intake necessary."

Sturgeon Lake Water System:

Mr. Walker advises that according to reports received from Father LaJoie, all land work scheduled for the Sturgeon Lake installation, consisting of excavating trenches, laying pipe, back-filling, connecting pipe and installing pressure tank, has been done. It has been noted, however, that Mr. Walker had suggested to the principal of this school that it was advisable to endeavour to excavate some 450 lineal feet of trench into the lake. When Mr. Nelson visited this school he was told that it was considered feasible to undertake this latter work by hand. Any other method such as shipping a power excavator to Sturgeon Lake was considered too expensive for so small a job. However, in a later report, dated November 27th, Father LaJoie advised Mr. Walker that so far they had not been successful in extending the trench into deep water by hand methods.
Mr. Walker has written the principal of this school, Father Fournier, asking him if he considered that this trench could be extended into the lake by working through the ice after the ice was about 6" thick. Mr. Walker further advised that if this method was not feasible, then urgently funds would have to be provided for drilling a well estimated to cost $500.00. Mr. Walker advises, however, that no reply has as yet been received from the principal of the school, Father Fournier, with regard to this matter.

If it is found necessary to drill a well, the pump house and pipeline from the lake can remain as it is for use when the lake is not too low or frozen over, and would be available at certain times for fire protection and possibly could be converted later into years of standby supply if some feasible method can be found to deepen the intake into the lake. Mr. Walker considers this an important point as from the standpoint of fire protection, it is to the advantage of the school to secure water from the lake if possible.

From the above it will be noted that at the end of November, Mr. Walker's information was not complete enough to allow of a definite estimate of funds required or work to be done. However, in his report Mr. Walker submits the following statement as being the best he can supply under the circumstances for funds required and report on work done or proposed:

Total Estimated expenditure for season $1,500.00

(B) Work done: Pipe laid and connected in trenches and to installed pressure tanks. Trench into lake started but not completed.

(C) Work to be done: Trench into lake to be completed by working through ice if possible. If impossible then well to be drilled at an estimated additional cost of $500.00."

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle.

Re: Water Supply for Indian Residential Schools at Grouard, Joussard, Fort Vermilion and Sturgeon Lake.

Since receipt of your memorandum of the 13th instant, we have taken up the above question with Mr. Young, Chief Geologist of the Geological Survey, and quote a letter from him as follows:

"I have received your memorandum of December 19 asking if we have any information regarding the possibilities of securing water by wells for certain Indian Residential Schools in Alberta. I am afraid we have not much information of value but what we have is being collected and will be sent to you.

"You also ask if we know anything of the qualifications of Mr. J.L. Germain of Montreal who has been represented as being a radio-physic prospector of great experience specializing in the finding of water and drilling of wells. We have no information about Mr. Germain. I suggest that if you are considering employing him that you require him to indicate in some detail the method or methods he would employ and that he be asked to state what equipment he has. I am told that reputable companies claim some measure of success in determining the presence or absence of water-bearing horizons. Such a company is Henry Lundberg Limited, Victory Building, Toronto. I do not think they would guarantee to find indications of water and you might consider their scale of charges high."

It will be noted that Mr. Young is having collected what information he has on the areas in question to be forwarded later. As soon as same is received you will then be advised.

With regard to the employment of a water prospector, I may say that we concur in the inference in Mr. Young's remarks that there is hardly enough factual information available as to the reliability of results obtained by such prospectors particularly in view of the possibly rather high cost as intimated by Mr. Young to warrant giving serious consideration to the proposal of employing any such prospectors.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing herewith vouchers showing how
the sum of $1,700.00 forwarded by the Department to St-Bernard's Mission for the installation of water has been spent.
I have delayed rendering account hoping to have for the next
mail all figures for a final report. Unfortunately, the work
is not completed yet. We are so far from supplies that more
than once we have been delayed several days waiting for a
small piece of fitting.

It is obvious by the account rendered that the
sum of $1,700.00 is far from covering all the expenses. En-
closed a preliminary statement of the cost. We have not to
wonder if the cost runs over the first estimates. Nobody
could know ahead how deep we should go to get water. The
engineer had figured a 200 feet well and water was en-
countered only at 702 feet. The working equipment having to
be rated on the depth of the well, a certain amount had to
added on this item. The higher increase comes from the drill-
ing and the material used. It will be a few days yet before
I know precisely how much will be credited on casing returned
to Beatty Pros Ltd.

As our batteries are already overloaded, we
have decided after undertaking with the engineering Office
at Banff to use a gasoline engine to pump from the well. It
means that the new house has to be larger and then more expen-
sive than figured at the start. For the pumping from the cistern,
(19,500 gallons cistern in the new Boys' Building), we in-
tend to use two small automatic pumps we have here. Would not
this teaming of pumps work, we would have to buy a new pump
costing about $200.00. We hope not to have to do so.

Remains the question of financing. I have had
to borrow from the Bank to pay the most urgent bills especially
the men's wages. Some firms are asking for money. May I expect
that the Department will find soon the way of financing the
expense exceeding $1,700.00? A requisition at that effect
should have been made by the engineering Office at Banff.
Receiving this would help me a lot.

Let me profit by this opportunity to thank you
for the interest you have paid to this important problem of
water supply in our Schools. If we succeed to get an adequate
water supply in our Missions, a great improvement will have
been realized.

Yours very truly,

F. S. LaJoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

Grouard, Alta., Sept. 5th, 1941.

Mr. Phillip Phelan, Chief, Training Div.,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

When in Ottawa last spring, I had understood from our conversations that the Department had no objection that the special allocations made for repairs and equipment in our Schools be used mostly on the Sturgeon Lake School which is crumbling. It appears now that the allotment should be applied to the very School it was formerly appropriated. I would appreciate receiving an official list of the monies voted for each of our Schools. I can't trace any such list here.

In order to reduce the expenses, we have decided to turn in flour the wheat harvested on our farms. Having been offered of a Milling Mill at a very low price, the offer has not been turned down. I presume that it will not be out of order to charge this mill.

The financial situation is getting serious. As outlined a year ago, we are feeling the burden of the war. In many lines, the prices are doubled or about. And while the other citizens enjoy an increase of revenues by way of wages or bonus, the Indian Schools have been cut by 7.76% of their revenues. No doubt that the authorities of the Department are sympathetically the situation in order to afford effective remedy.

Thanking you in advance for the attention you will give to this question, I remain, Dear Mr. Phelan,

Yours truly,

F. S. LaJoie, O.M.I.

Grouard, Alta.

Extract from letter dated May 1, 1942, received from Rev. G. Forcade, O.M.I.

Referring to my request last February for linoleum to cover our Gymnastic Hall, I would add that, should it not be covered with material of this kind, it will still be necessary, before very long, to spend considerably on repairs of this floor. Were these done with concrete and paint, it would not better the sanitary condition. I am not pressing you as I feel you are giving this request your careful attention.
Ottawa,
May 6, 1942.

EX D

Reverend Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the last instant, in which you again mention the necessity for covering the hall at the Grouard Residential School with linoleum.

This would involve considerable expense and we are not prepared to give the matter further consideration unless specially requested to do so by Bishop Langlois. As you are probably aware, the amounts provided for Church-owned Indian residential schools are specifically stated in our appropriation and cannot be exceeded. Bishop Langlois is endeavoring to improve the conditions at the Sturgeon Lake School and consequently has expressed the desire that we do not spend any money for repairs and improvements at other residential schools in his Diocese without his express request.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. G. Forcade, O.M.I.,
Grouard Indian Residential School,
Grouard, Alta.
Mr. R.A.Hoey,

Dear Sir:

We have had the projector on trial and concluded that it was not entirely satisfactory. The University informed us since that for projection of postcards, satisfaction could be obtained only on a special screen which costs $36.00. I plan to go to the University and see just what it gives. We are very thankful for your kind assistance in this matter.

The children and I have just completed the building of a printing shop, and a dark room for photography in their school house. This has given them much enthusiasm as they are accurate and neat in this kind of work.

Mr. J.H.Ross and Dr. G.F.McNally who have recently paid us a visit both said they were very satisfied with the kind and quality of activities this school was carrying on with the children.

Thanking you once again,

I remain,

Yours truly,

C.Forcade, O.M.I.
Leader.
Mr. R.A.Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re-131-15.

Recovering our gymnastic hall with linoleum, I have discussed your letter with Bishop Langlois. I readily understand it would be unfair for me to ask for more than we have when the Sturgeon Lake school is in a state of dismal necessity.

I am not acquainted with the status of Church owned school. Whatever be the case, I am sure the Government cannot help but recognize the enormous contribution the Church itself is giving it in this kind of work. May I also point out that the Youth Training Programme we are carrying out here is most genuine "vocational training". Out of five of my trainees this year who became eligible for military purposes, four made their application and three have been accepted. The three of them are leaving for England very shortly. Eighteen of our old pupils are in the army...most of them in England.

Mr. J.H.Ross who has just visited our Youth Training Centre has noticed that whilst our vocational work was being promoted in the most efficient way, our gymnastic hall could bare to be improved for better health and better results. I therefor maintain my request for some governmental assistance in bettering the conditions we are in for physical training. We have taxed our energies and our revenues to the utmost this year for the welfare of the children and this is why we feel somehow justified in asking for some outside help. I trust you will do everything possible to meet our demand.

Yours respectfully,

G. Porcade, O.M.I.
Leader.
Ottawa, June 18, 1942.

Dear Father Forcade:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 9, in which you discuss again the desirability of securing a sufficient quantity of linoleum to cover the floor of your gymnastic hall.

We are communicating with Bishop Langlois, in the hope that it may be possible to secure funds from the appropriation set apart for the repair of church-owned schools, to enable us to purchase the linoleum you may require. There is always the possibility, of course, that it may be exceedingly difficult to secure linoleum at this particular time. I have been informed by a number of men, responsible for the organization of physical culture classes, that it is possible to treat the cement floor with certain chemicals and later paint it with a coat or two of gray paint, and that the results are reasonably satisfactory. I have been wondering if at any time you have thought of this treatment.

It is altogether likely that you shall hear from us again, just as soon as we receive a letter from Bishop Langlois.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Reverend G. Forcade, O.M.I.,
St. Bernard's Mission,
Grouard, Alberta.

Dear Father Forcade,

It has been brought to my attention that the school power plant is being over-taxed due to the operations of your handicraft plant, and it has been suggested that we endeavour to locate for your use a small diesel plant to power the machines which you use in your work.

If a plant suitable for your work can be found surplus to the requirements of some other government department, we will try to secure this for you. In order that we may advise the various departments the size of plant required, will you please furnish me with the following information:

1. How many machines do you operate?
2. Describe each machine and the purpose for which it is used.
3. Give the voltage of each machine, number of cycles, and the wattage consumed by each machine?
4. The total wattage of lights used.
5. The power required for any other purposes, such as pumps.
6. The peak load.

You might also estimate for future requirements, that is any additional machines you propose to install, additional lights, etc., giving the above information in regard to them.

You understand, of course, that we do not guarantee to furnish a plant, but we will see what can be found on receipt of the information asked for.

Yours very truly,

R.A. Rosey,

May 29th. 1945.

Dept. of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Can.

ATTENTION MR. PHELAN

While visiting our Indian Residential Schools at Joussard and Grouard, the Indian boys attending these schools brought to my attention that they were badly in need of supplies for playing baseball. I would like to mention that this is about the only game in the summer time that they are really interested in, and they do play a good game, but they need a few gloves, balls and bats. At the time that Mr. McCrimmon went through here for the Treaty Payment, I mentioned this to him, and asked if the Department would assist in getting a few of these articles, and he replied that he thought they would, and to write to you for these things. Therefore I would respectfully ask for a contribution of $30.00 to make up a good enough outfit for the boys of these two schools. I am sure that these boys would greatly appreciate this, as they are very fond of this game.

I would be very pleased to receive an early reply, as the season is going by.

P.J. Demers
Indian Agent.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES.
CANADA
Driftpile, Alberta, Oct. 9, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa

In past years it has been customary to pay the residential schools in this agency $40.00 per month for a night watchman for winter months.

As I am unaware of what months they are to be paid for, I am asking your confirmation of same.

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 16 October 1946.

Mr. A. Landry, Indian Agent,
DRIFTPILE, Alberta.

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant, the Department is prepared to allow an amount of $40.00 a month for a period of seven months towards the salary of a night watchman at each of the following schools in your Agency:- Grouard, Joussard, Sturgeon Lake, Vermilion, Wabasca C.E., and Wabasca R.C., and Whitefish Lake.

The period for which we usually allow is from Oct. 1 to the subsequent April 30th.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of welfare & Training.
**DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES**

**INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH**

Dear Sir:

The undersigned visited the Indian School and Mission at Brantford today, and discussed the water supply and results of well drilling and dug wells with Father Tessier.

According to the information as I understand it, a deep well was drilled to a depth of over 700 feet. The quality of this water was apparently somewhat similar to that which was obtained in the hospital well at M. Lemoine, drilled to 652 feet. This shows that the hospital well at M. Lemoine, drilled to 652 feet, the shallow well at Lemoine is quite muddy when freshly pumped. This tendency is due to fine clay material held in suspension in the water.

The deep wells at M. Lemoine are considered to be drilled to the base of a marine formation known as the Smoky River Shale. No suitable water has ever been known to have been obtained in this marine shale bed. The underlying formation, known as the Dunegan, may have some suitable water at its base, but this is considered to be at around 1000 feet from surface. Therefore, at Brantford, since no previous drilling has proved the existence of suitable water at this depth, it is not recommended that a well to this depth be tried.

It was reported that a bed of fine sand, estimated to be 20 feet in thickness, had been encountered in both drilling and in digging for water at the Mission buildings. However, this sand was always of such fineness that it gave trouble in the well, and also the quality of the water obtained was high in iron content and low in hardness.

In my opinion that if this bed of sand was at one time a part of the lake bottom, that the deposit might continue downward.
toward higher ground, and if it were an old lake beach,
that the material contained would tend to be closer to a
shore line and therefore coarser, such as coarse sand or gravel.
It is also thought that water held in fine or coarse gravel
would probably be free of its own content and thereby
result in quality. This fine sand material may also be along other
glacial deposits, and glacial gravel could be in association.

It is further proposed that a test hole or holes might
be drilled eastward for possibly 1/4 mile toward the eastern
boundary of the property. This is proceeding higher up the
slope of the hill, and farther from the existing lake. The
purpose of these test holes would be so that the fine sand
deposit found at 30 feet at the buildings. If these sands
lead to become coarser, or to become a gravel bed, thus
it is thought a sufficient and suitable quality of water
may be obtained from a well possibly 25 to 100 feet
in depth. If such were obtained in a test hole,
this company would construct a suitably sized well complete
with proper steel well casing and using a continuous pump
test on the well for, say 48 hours, until the quantity of water to
be obtained had been assured. A sample of water would

This water could possibly consist of 6 to 8 feet below, with
a total of say 250 or 300 feet of drilling. Then possibly a
permanent well at the most suitable location.

It is proposed that if suitable quality quantities of water
could be located even maintain a distribution of the water from

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st instant in reference to a copy of a letter received from the Director of Indian Affairs, asking to be advised if a water resources survey had been made in the area of Grouard and if a well could be dug at a cost of not more than $4000 to give a sufficient supply for 225 persons under Bishop Langlois of Episcopal Corporation of Grouard.

As instructed, I have made contact with Mr. D. F. Hamelin of Donegal Mansions, Sunnyside Blvd, Calgary, and wish to report as follows.

Mr. Hamelin advises me that he is a graduate in geology from the University of California and took a postgraduate year at Stanford. Mr. Hamelin has apparently had considerable experience in well-drilling. One of his jobs of Transport and one of the last jobs completed with that Department was at Whitecourt, Alberta. Mr. Hamelin confers with Dr. Allen and other geologists in Alberta and on account of such contacts, along with his education, appears to have a grounding in geological knowledge that would be most useful in well-drilling work.

The survey as requested by the Indian Affairs Director has apparently not been made and no one can say definitely that the water is available at the particular location in question. Mr. Hamelin is, however, optimistic that a shallow well might tap a sufficient supply for, say, 7500 gallons at the above school.

For a well one-hundred (100) feet deep, his firm, he estimated, could drill it at approximately the following cost.

| Item                                      | Cost   |
|-------------------------------------------|--------|
| 200 hours of drilling time                | @ $2.00 | $1,600.00 |
| 50 feet of 8" Casing                      | @ 3.00  | 150.00     |
| 100 feet of 5" Casing                     | @ 1.50  | 150.00     |
| Transfer charges, drilling equipment      |        | 100.00     |
| Travelling expenses of Mr. Hamelin or his assistant to Grouard, etc. |        | 100.00     |

If a shallow well were found where a suction pump could be used, the pumping equipment might range from $175.00 to $300.00.

If it was a deep well, the pumping device might cost up to $600.00

Hence, if pumping equipment cost $600, Total Cost $2,700.00

Exigencies, 10%                            | 270.00 |
Grand Total                                | $2,970.00 |
If the well is a shallow one, the cost may be accordingly reduced, whereas if it be considered advisable to go deeper than one hundred feet, it might cost more.

In any case, I believe Mr. Hamelin to be a suitable driller and would suggest that he be engaged to drill the Grouard well. His rig is at present near that area.

(Sgd.) O.H. Hoover,
District Chief Engineer.

Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

We are in receipt of your memorandum of July 12th re the proposed well at Grouard Indian Residential School and attached report from Mr. O.H. Hoover, District Engineer of the Surveys and Engineering Branch in Calgary. The following information is taken from R.L. Rutherford's Report #21 (1930) of the Research Council of Alberta, entitled Geology and Water Resources in Parts of the Peace River and Grande Prairie Districts, Alta. While Rutherford's survey extended only to a few miles east of McLennan, Alta. (Twp.77, Rge.19 W.5th), we have utilized it in order to predict as closely as possible the continuation of conditions eastward to the Grouard location in Twp.75, Rge.14, W.5th.

Accordingly, the Grouard area and that covered by the Research Council's report are both underlain by the Smoky River Shales beneath which lies the Dunvegan Formation comprising an alternating series of sandstones and shales, the former known to be water-bearing. Above the bedrock lies an unknown thickness of glacial drift and Recent alluvium. Such drift is commonly composed of impervious boulder clay with lenses or pockets of sand and gravel scattered throughout which may be good aquifers. The base of the drift is also a common groundwater horizon. Thus there appears to be three chances for obtaining an adequate supply: a shallow well tapping sand or gravel deposits in the drift; the plane of contact between the drift and bedrock; or from the sandy members of the Dunvegan Formation.

In the McLennan area, existing geological conditions indicate that a good supply of water cannot be obtained from the upper strata. Dug and bored wells here are usually less than 100' deep, mostly penetrating clays and shales of the drift and the water where obtained is extremely hard. It is recorded...
that a few shallow wells which have penetrated superficial coarse glacial deposits or peat bogs produced good water. Assuming similar surface conditions around Grouard, it may be possible by sinking test holes prior to digging to discover a satisfactory shallow sand or gravel aquifer. Otherwise digging at random would be hazardous.

Drilled wells are a more satisfactory source. Some have been recorded as penetrating the sandy layers of the Dunvegan Formation and getting water which, although not hard, is inclined to be salty. However, here we have the problem of depth. In McGlenan several such wells went to over 650' in depth before striking a Dunvegan water horizon. The Formation outcrops toward the north and dips southward, (Map #14, Report #21) hence since Grouard is farther south than McGlenan, the depth to the same aquifer would be greater, and salty water is frequently found at such depth. From the standpoint of drilling costs, therefore, it would be inadvisable to try for this horizon.

We have no information regarding groundwater at the base of the drift. This could be tested before drilling by sinking an auger hole. Regarding depth to bedrock, an oil well drilled at High Prairie (Twp.74, Rge.17,W.5th) recorded 668' of surface deposits, which, again because of the southerly regional dip, should not be as great around Grouard, in the absence of local hills. No water was reported from the drift in this well, although much of the deposition was sand.

From the above you will see that the best course seems to be that of primarily sinking test holes in the surface deposits, penetrating, if necessary, down to bedrock, in hope of encountering a sand or gravel aquifer therein, or a source at the top of the bedrock. Unless such a horizon is encountered near the surface, the well may have to be drilled even up to 650' to reach a satisfactory supply, but at least the possibilities can be explored in this manner at no great expense.

B.R. MacKay,
Chief, Borings, Fuels and Groundwater Section.

Ottawa, July 16th, 1947.

January 12, 1948.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Destruction by fire of Electric Plant at Grouard School

My dear Mr. Phelan,

I am in receipt of a telegram from His Excellency Bishop Routhier, in which he states that the electric plant of the Grouard school was completely destroyed by fire on December 31st 1947.

The school is now lighted by a make-shift plant which is of such a temporary nature that it must be replaced immediately.

This electric plant was used for pumping water and servicing the various departments where small electric motors were in use. It is, therefore, essential that no time be lost in replacing it. Bishop Routhier is most anxious to hear when the Department will place the order for a new plant.

We are informed by Fairbanks Morris of Edmonton that a 10 KW generator with Diesel engine and batteries would cost $4042.00. In order to expedite the matter Bishop Routhier would appreciate being authorized to place the order himself and forward invoices to the Department.

Hoping that the above will receive your immediate attention, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
Ottawa, January 15, 1947.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary

Monsieur :

Il y a tantôt 50 ans que je m'occupe des Indiens dans ce pays du Nord, et plus de 44 que je me trouve plus ou moins en rapport avec l'éducation donnée aux jeunes Indiens dans les écoles de l'Alberta Nord. Aujourd'hui, je voici principal de l'école Indienne de Rouard, Alberta. J'en suis venu avec vous, Monsieur, à cette conclusion qu'il faudrait faire quelque chose de pratique pour nos jeunes Indiens. Les filles apprennent la couture, la cuisine, la tenue d'une maison; très bien, mais nos jeunes garçons ! Ici, nous avons commencé déjà à leur montrer à faire quelque chose par eux même : les objets qui leur seront nécessaires dans la vie qu'ils devront mener dans le bois: outils, canot, maison, quelque meubles, etc. Mais je ne puis oublier qui sont naturellement chasseurs et pêcheurs et je crois que le plus grand service qu'on pourrait leur rendre serait de les entraîner dans l'élevage des animaux à fourrure.

Hélas ! Ces espèces d'animaux disparaissent vite dans notre Nord autrefois si riche en fourrures. Dejà même beaucoup sont entièrement disparus. Quand je pense que nos Indiens pour vivre en sont réduits à chasser l'écureuil qu'on ne regardait même pas il y a quelques années, tout comme l'hermine d'ailleurs !

À Rouard, situé à l'extrémité ouest du Petit Lac des Esclaves en Alberta, nous avons une place idéale pour ce nouveau genre d'industrie. Nous pouvons trouver sur place et facilement et sans beaucoup de frais, tout ce qui serait nécessaire, et je sais avec quel plaisir, quel entrain nos élèves se porteraient à ce genre de travail si conforme à leurs goûts. Plus tard, ce pourrait être pour eux un moyen assez facile de se procurer le vivre et le couvert.

Et voilà pourquoi, Mr. le Surintendant, j'ose venir vous demander d'avoir la bonté de nous fournir quelques couples de visons pour commencer notre œuvre ici. Ce qui m'encourage c'est que nous savons ici que déjà vous avez encouragé certaine école dans cette voie.

Et ce serait même avec plaisir que je recevrais les conseils que votre expérience voudrait bien me suggérer et m'aider ainsi à faire une réussite dans ce genre d'éducation tout nouveau à Grouard.

J'ai l'honneur d'être, Monsieur le Surintendant,

Votre tout dévoué,

Extract from Inspector Schmidt's report on the Grouard Indian residential school visited on November 28, 1938:

**MANUAL TRAINING**

**Boys:** The older boys help with the chores around the institution, and get a good general training in farming, gardening, care of live stock, horses, and general repair work, under the supervision of the lay brothers who live at the mission. They are in charge of this work, and have a complete line of carpenter's, blacksmith's and mechanic's tools. The Principal intends using part of the basement, under the school (class) room for a manual training shop for the boys. He remarked that they had no tools, and could not very well borrow same from the mission brothers to use in this shop. I suggested that a requisition for same be submitted without delay, and that this boys' shop be opened and going as soon as possible.

**Girls:** The girls do general house-work: cooking, baking, laundry, knitting, sewing, mending, patching. They also make new clothes for both the boys and themselves. They are, however, more or less handicapped for sewing, as they have no proper sewing room. This matter I will take up under the heading of Buildings.

**CLASS-ROOMS:** A separate frame building having four lovely large, well-lighted class-rooms, is used. This is heated by a hot-air furnace and is very comfortable. It has a full-sized basement, part of which the Principal intends to partition off for the purpose of establishing a manual training shop for the boys, who will work under the supervision of one of the brothers.

(Sgd.) C. P. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am in receipt of Mr. Jackson's memorandum of August 2 enclosing the attached requisition which includes 8 sewing machines for the Grouard Indian Residential School.

This school is located in the Diocese of Grouard and there are four other schools in the same Diocese; namely, Sturgeon Lake, Vermilion, Joussard and Wabasca R.C. His Lordship Bishop Lajeunesse is extremely interested in providing advanced domestic training for the older girls of these five schools. Last year he made arrangements for two or three of the Sisters to take a special course in domestic science and for the academic year 1940-41 he intends to bring to Grouard from the other four residential schools in his Diocese the most capable older girls in order that they may have the advantage of a year's course in advanced domestic science under the guidance of trained Sisters.

As these girls will be included in the number of regular grant-earning pupils this special programme will not involve any extra expense to the Department other than the equipment of the rooms in which domestic science will be taught. The cost of the equipment will be taken from the amount provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs, improvements and new equipment at the Grouard Indian Residential School.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6366, file 761-11, part 1)
In order to have sufficient sewing machines available for those taking the course the number shown on the attached requisition are required.

I feel that this is an excellent course for the older girls and is preferable to advanced academic training for them. Under these circumstances I recommend that the equipment included on the requisition be purchased.

In the second paragraph of Mr. Jackson's memorandum he refers to the purchase of sewing machines. It has always been our practice to supply a few of these to each residential school in order that the staff and the older girls may make clothing required for the pupils. If you do not wish sewing machines to be supplied in the future please let me know.

You will note, however, that the sewing machines requested for Grouard are for a special course and not for general use in the school.

Director.
The pupils of the Domestic School of Grouard are doing excellent work. At the time of my visit, they had sixty-three complete boys' suits already packed to be sent to Joussard School. Rev. Sister Eustache, who is in charge, told me that those had been made within a month's time and beside other works. The girls also take lessons in cooking, washing, ironing, knitting and all kinds of fancy works. I was very much interested in the practical cooking lessons given to them which include meat curing, smoking and canning and sausage making etc... They also learn to take care of milk and cream, as well as butter making. The pupils have been picked from Joussard, Sturgeon Lake, Wabasca Fort Vermilion and Grouard Residential Schools. There are thirteen of them.

It was brought to my attention, by His Lordship, Bishop Langlais and Rev. Father Habay Principal of Grouard School, that something similar to Domestic School should be attempted with the boys, if we wish to make a success with the young Indians. They intimated that, as long as the boys will have nothing to do when they come out of schools, all our good work with the girls will be useless. They suggested that, if the boys of a certain age could be taken to a school especially organized for them under a competent person and taught a trade along with farming, we could expect some results, as they would be in better position to make a home and provide for those girls, whenever they get married. Of course the boys would have to remain there until they are eighteen years old.

Dear Reverend Friends, and Girls and Boys of Grouard Mission:

Sister Jean has given me the opportunity of expressing my appreciation for all your hospitality and the opportunity of seeing so much that was interesting and also seeing in person so many who were only names previously.

All persons connected with the Grouard Mission are to be congratulated on the progressive outlook of this educational institution and the very friendly spirit which prevails.

There are so many features to which I should refer but will content myself with mentioning a few which appealed to me particularly - the remarkable cleanliness of your premises on a muddy day - and yet it was a pleasant and comfortable cleanliness with no feeling of rigidity; the value of your system of uniforms and rank badges with the corresponding responsibility of living up to the standard; the quality of the physical work in "fundamentals" and dancing - I was delighted with the singing; the steam baths - a great deal of credit is due to Father Forcade for his perseverance and ingenuity with respect to this activity. He has made a contribution, not only to your School but to the general problem of bathing, etc.

One could continue listing pleasant memories but wet weather at that time and space now forbids. Sometime in the future I hope to renew my acquaintance with you when the boys probably will be able to take me over the School "Farm" and show me another group of splendid achievements of the pupils and Staff of your School, which is a credit to your Church and the Indian Department.

You may be interested to know we arrived in Edmonton on time after further experience with mud and seeing a big black bear. To all, my sincerest thanks for a pleasant and educative experience.

Once again, "Aur Revoir".

(sgd.) Joe.H.Ross.

Dear Sister Jean:

I should like you to know how much Mr. Ross and I appreciated the opportunity we had last week of seeing something of the work of the St. Bernard Mission. Not to make my letter too long I shall confine my comments to two or three matters.

First, we were greatly impressed with the neatness and home-likeness of the classrooms of the school. Indeed, I cannot remember when I have seen rooms so brisk and spry. Coupled with this was the evident happiness of the children. I had formed that opinion of the Mission children from reading the "Echoes" but was hardly prepared to find the feeling so general.

Then we were so pleased with the Health and Recreation program. The degree of excellence reached by both girls and boys would have done credit to classes which had been in training much longer than those at the Mission. Nor must I forget the splendid baths. These, I am sure, account in large measure for the healthy, happy appearance of all the children. On our way home Mr. Ross commented more than once on the high standard of results which you have attained.

And, lastly, I must mention again what I said when speaking to the children. The Mission provides a first-rate opportunity for an all-round education. In addition to the regular school subjects the girls get training in the domestic arts under conditions which approach nearly to those to be found in the homes which we hope they are going to have. A similar training on the farm for the boys will make the opportunity complete. I can think of hundreds of boys and girls in Alberta for whom I could wish just such a well-balanced education.

Our visit was all too short but left us with a definite desire to repeat it.

Very sincerely yours,

(Sgd) G. Fred McNally,
Deputy Minister

Dear Mr. Hoey:

On May 26th, Mr. G. Fred McNally, Deputy Minister of Education of Alberta, and Mr. Joe H. Ross, of the Dominion-Provincial Youth Training, honoured the Grouard Indian School with their visit. Their visit was short on account of the inclement weather, it having rained continuously during the preceding night, and the rainfall threatening to continue for some length of time. You, no doubt, know the plight of the motorist on a 275 mile trip on gumbo roads soaked by rain.

I take pleasure in enclosing copy of the respective letters, perhaps somewhat mandatory, received from these distinguished visitors, by Sister Jean Placidus, directress of "The Grouard Echoes". You will doubtless appreciate reading these letters which deal with a work to which you have devoted your best years.

I simply wish to call your attention to the wish expressed by both these gentlemen, to see, beginning next Fall, for the older boys of our Indian Schools, a post-school course equivalent to that which we are endeavouring to organize for the older girls. This work is essential and should be undertaken by your Department as soon as possible, war or no war. Dear Mr. Hoey:

The more I study the people here, the more I see it is necessary for us to teach them how to earn their living. To make them feel this, you must create some ambition in them. I am directing my activities towards industries among them. We have begun this in class. One of our activities is leather work and bead work. We show them how to make use of their skill and the value of it in leather crafts. We are more or less boycotted through lack of material and especially beads. Do you know of some channels through which we could get them? You will hear more about this through our ECHOES.

I remain,

Dear Father Forcade:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant and to state that I was more than delighted to learn of the attempts you are making to promote worthwhile handicraft projects at your school. It is my hope that you will be as successful in this regard as you have been in the development of your physical courses.

We have experienced the utmost difficulty in securing beads. In this connection we have communicated with a number of agencies in the Dominion, including a representative of Czecho Slovakia. It would appear that beads are not available at this time, nor are they likely to be available at any time in the immediate future. However, we have on hand a small quantity of small white beads, and we would be prepared to send forward 5 pounds, should you consider such a small quantity of any value to you. I am personally of the opinion that Indians, for the time being, should be encouraged to take up handicraft work which does not involve the use of beads.
