Dear Sir:

About two and a half years ago I was appointed Assistant Principal at the Grouard Indian Residential School. On my arrival I found that Indian handicraft had almost disappeared from the school and, as the authorities were anxious that it should be re-established as soon as possible, I immediately began to interest the children in this particular activity.

Along with my endeavours as far as the school children were concerned I also tried to interest the former girl pupils of the school and their parents, with the result that in a relatively short time moccasins, gloves, curios of various kinds and even buckskin coats and parkas were being made in reasonable quantities by both the older school girls and the former pupils of the school living either on the reserve or close to the school.

The result of these various activities was that we found ourselves with about $4000.00 worth of these articles for which we found a very ready market with the Hudson's Bay Company and the American tourists, as well as the employees of the various companies that were working on the Alaska road project.

The skins for all these articles were bought from the local Indians and from the Hudson's Bay Company, as well as from the Indians of British Columbia. As we ran out of materials we attempted to purchase skins from the Indians of Ontario, as well as from those of the Mackenzie District, but we found that transportation costs were too high and we consequently had to curtail our production.

I believe that I am quite within the truth when I say that about 60% of the women of the reserve, ranging in years from 22 up, worked for the school along with the children and that the above families shared, in various degrees, in this amount of $4000.00, with the result that a great deal of personal pride was taken in the work they were doing and a consequent betterment in social conditions resulted.
This experience has led me to believe that something basically sound could be established for the older pupils of the Grouard School, as well as the former ones, if we could arrive at a more standardized method of production. For the last three weeks I have been investigating manufacturing conditions among the Indians of Little Lorette in the Province of Quebec and the results that these people have obtained by the establishment of small manufacturing plants, some of which are even housed in private homes, are proof that something similar could be set on foot in Northern Alberta for our Indians.

I have three projects in view which I am now submitting to you for your kind consideration and approval, if you should see fit to do so. The first of these projects is one for the manufacturing of standard models of moccasins, house slippers, work mitts and gloves. For the time being the leather for these various articles would be bought from the regular sources, but later on it would be our ambition to utilize the skins of the wild animals of Northern Alberta, as well as the domestic skins that could easily be bought from the Indians and the white settlers of our district.

The second project would be the establishment of a sawmill. There is, in the territory closely adjacent to our Grouard School, considerable timber which could be turned out into boards and building lumber at a reasonable cost, provided (and that, of course, would be our aim) only local labour was used.

My third project would be the setting up of a small tannery. I am now learning the tanning business in an amateurish way, but I am informed that the data which is being given to me now by one of the leading tanners of the City of Quebec will be sufficient for what we have in view for our Indians.

For the present I would like the Government to help me in the purchase of the material which will be necessary for the manufacture of the moccasins and other articles mentioned above.
Later on, if this project is a success, I will take the liberty of asking the Government to help me in the two other projects.

I hope, dear Mr. Hoey, that the above rough outline of my ambitions regarding the social uplift of our Indians will be sufficient to induce you to grant the help which I am now seeking.

Yours very truly,

G. Forcade, O.M.I.
Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,

The following is a list of the machines and accessories for the manufacture of house slippers that can be bought from A. Gagnon, Loretteville, Que., and delivery of which could be had immediately:

2. 2 Union special sewing machines for soles and assembling;
3. 1 Singer machine for sewing the binding on moccasins;
4. 2 Singer machines for assembling;
5. All the dies for soles from size 3 to size 8;
6. 800 pairs of forms for babies', boys' girls', women's and men's slippers;
7. Patterns for all the above forms;

10. Shafting, hangers and transmission pulleys for above machinery;

We are given to understand that the above machinery is in first-class order and is fully guaranteed by the owner. We did not have the opportunity to examine the machinery, but we did see the forms, the dies, the tables and other accessories and none of these articles showed any appreciable wear. This leads us to believe that the owner's recommendation can be accepted at its full value.

The price asked for the above was $1000.00, but on learning that this machinery was needed for an Indian school the owner kindly consented to reduce the price by $200.00.
On information gathered from various manufacturers of house slippers and moccasins, we are of the opinion that this machinery will be quite sufficient to start us in business and that with it we can manufacture a readily salable product.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

I am sending forward herewith copies of two letters received by me from the Reverend Father Forcade, of the Grouard Residential School.

Subject to your approval, I would like to ask Mr. Doucet, who is at present at Restigouche, to visit Lorette on his return journey and make an inspection of the machinery referred to in this correspondence. If, in Mr. Doucet's judgment, this machinery is in good, serviceable condition and suitable for the organization of a worthwhile handicraft project, I would recommend its purchase by the Department for the Grouard School. The purchase price - approximately $300.00 - should, in my judgment, be charged to the amount set apart annually for the promotion of handicraft. You are aware that, although we have an official in charge of handicraft promotion in the Branch, we have been spending very little money on this work at any time during the last two or three years.

Father Forcade, who is at present in Quebec, taking a course of training in the tanning and processing of leather and in the manufacture of gloves and slippers, and with whom I have discussed this proposal at considerable length, informs me that he could provide work for a great many men and women in the Grouard district by the establishment of this industry. A large number of young men from the Grouard district joined the Armed Forces and are now serving overseas. It is just possible that the establishment of an industry such as this would provide employment for them in the immediate post-war period. In any event, Father Forcade has done very effective work in the organization of the school courses at Grouard and in the organization of the pupils, particularly the senior pupils. He is now taking a course of training at his own expense.
and it is somewhat difficult for me to see how we can withhold this assistance.

R. A. Hoey,
Acting Director.

I am sending forward herewith copies of two letters received by me from the Reverend Father Forcade, of the Grouard Residential School.

Subject to your approval, I would like to ask Mr. Doucet, who is at present at Restigouche, to visit Lorette on his return journey and make an inspection of the machinery referred to in this correspondence. If, in Mr. Doucet's judgment, this machinery is in good, serviceable condition and suitable for the organization of a worthwhile handicraft project, I would recommend its purchase by the Department for the Grouard School. The purchase price - approximately $800.00 - should, in my judgment, be charged to the amount set apart annually for the promotion of handicraft. You are aware that, although we have an official in charge of handicraft promotion in the Branch, we have been spending very little money on this work at any time during the last two or three years.

Father Forcade, who is at present in Quebec, taking a course of training in the tanning and processing of leather and in the manufacture of gloves and slippers, and with whom I have discussed this proposal at considerable length, informs me that he could provide work for a great many men and women in the Grouard district by the establishment of this industry. A large number of young men from the Grouard district joined the Armed Forces and are now serving overseas. It is just possible that the establishment of an industry such as this would provide employment for them in the immediate post-war period. In any event, Father Forcade has done very effective work in the organization of the school courses at Grouard and in the organization of the pupils, particularly the senior pupils. He is now taking a course of training at his own expense.

Report on four samples of clay submitted by Rev. Father G. Porcada, Grouard, Alberta.

Four samples of clay, marked No. 1, 2, 3 and 4, were received with the request that they be examined to determine whether they could be used for pottery and handicraft work.

A physical examination of the four samples gave the following results:

| Sample No. | 1   | 2   | 3   | 4   |
|------------|-----|-----|-----|-----|
| Calcareous Sand | Non | Non | Non | Very gritty |
| Water of Plasticity % | 22.3 | 22.8 | 21.9 | 26.9 |
| Plasticity | Good | Good | Poor | Poor |
| Drying behaviour at 65°C | Good | Good | Good | Good |
| Softening point | Cone 4 | Cone 4 | Cone 4 | Cone 3 |
| Remarks | Highly carbonaceous | Highly carbonaceous | Highly carbonaceous |

Samples 1 and 2 have good working properties for a pottery clay but would be very difficult to fire due to their short vitrifying range and high carbon content. This type of body would also be difficult to glaze. Samples 3 and 4 have poor plasticity, and because of this and their sandy nature, would not have satisfactory working properties on a potter's wheel.

None of the four samples of clay tested could be classed as a satisfactory clay for use in pottery and handicraft work.

G. A. Kirkendale,
Ceramic Engineer,
Industrial Minerals Division.
Ottawa, August 28, 1943.

Memorandum to:
Mr. C. W. Jackson,
Chief Executive Assistant,
Department of Mines and Resources.

The four small samples of clay submitted through you by Rev. Father G. Forcade, Grouard, Alberta, were subjected to tests in our Ceramic Laboratory by G. A. Kirkendale, Ceramic Engineer. His report is herewith submitted, in duplicate.

As the samples were very small they could not be tested fully, but the information obtained is sufficient to judge their suitability for the making of craft pottery and I believe that Mr. Kirkendale's conclusions that the clays are not well suited for pottery making are justified.

I will be glad to discuss the matter with Father Forcade and suggest more suitable sources of clay.

Regulations Established Under Authority of
Section 94 B of the Indian Act, Chapter 96, R.S. 1927
as Amended by Chapter 31, 2 George VI.

1. These regulations and any amendments thereto may be cited as the Indian 'Revolving Fund' Regulations.

2. "Minister" shall mean the Minister of Mines and Resources.

3. "Director" shall mean the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

4. "Inspector" shall mean the Inspector of Indian Agencies in the Provinces of Quebec, Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta, and the Indian Commissioner for the Province of British Columbia.

5. There shall be a "Revolving Fund" in the amount of not more than three hundred and fifty thousand dollars as provided in Section 94 B of the Indian Act, Chapter 96, R.S. 1927, as amended by Chapter 31, George VI.

6. The Director may with the approval of the Minister grant loans from this fund to Indian Bands, groups or groups of Indians, or individual Indians for the purpose of farm implements, machinery, live stock, fishing and other equipment, seed grain and materials to be used in native handicrafts. The Minister may also, with the approval of the Minister, expend and loan money from the said fund for the carrying out of co-operative projects on behalf of the Indians.

7. (a) Loans to an Indian Band shall not exceed the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).

(b) Loans to a group or groups of Indians shall not exceed the sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00).

(c) Loans to an individual Indian shall not exceed the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00).

All such loans shall be repayable in five annual instalments with interest on the principal sum at the rate of five per cent (5%) per annum and shall be deposited to the credit of the revolving fund account. The restriction as to the amount of loans in this section mentioned shall not, however, apply in the case of co-operative projects on behalf of the Indians.

8. Loans made under these regulations to Indian Bands, groups or groups of Indians and individual Indians, and money expended or loaned for co-operative projects on behalf of the Indians, shall not in all exceed in any one year the sum of one hundred thousand dollars (100,000.00).

Reverend Sir:

I enclose, for your information, copy of a letter to Mr. N.P. L'Heureux, Indian Agent, Driftpile, Alberta, regarding the proposed application for loan from Revolving Fund, for the promotion of a craft project for the benefit of Indian workers near Grouard.

The regulations provide that such loans can be administered only through Departmental employees, but funds can be made available as soon as the loan in question is approved by the Minister, Honourable Mr. Crerar. If you do not require the whole amount of $1500.00 for immediate use, it would be wise to apply only for what is required, in order to save interest. The procedure is for this office to make an accountable advance to the Indian Agent, from which he can issue a definite sum to you. For any funds issued to you, you will be required to sign the Agent's cash book receipt form. You, in turn, must take receipts for every item of expenditure, and these receipts should be sent to the Indian Agent with a covering credit voucher or list, which, in turn, will be forwarded to Ottawa. Receipts covering all expenditures up to the full amount of the loan must, in due course, be presented to the Treasury Office by our Department.

Interest is charged at the rate of 5% per annum, and it would be advisable for you to set aside, toward the payment of interest and principal, at least one quarter of the money received for goods sold. You will see by the forms that the first payment on the

Rev. G. Forsade, O.M.I.,

loan must be made not later than November 1, 1944, but earlier payment will be to your advantage in the saving of interest.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Since I saw you last, I have been moving around a great deal. Back in the West, I travelled north with the Bishop and I am now on my way home. This accounts for the fact that I have given you no further information on my activities. I presume that Father Flourde has informed you, however, and I trust it was satisfactory to you.

I have purchased the equipment necessary for the making of boudoir slippers from Mr. A. Gagnon, Loretteville, P.C., and I had him send the account to your Department, as it was understood. Everything should be satisfactory in the equipment. I had the machines thoroughly inspected and I saw to the packing and the shipping of these myself.

In Calgary, I saw Mr. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Schools. He informed me of the procedure to be taken at Grouard by the Indians in asking the Department for a loan. I asked Mr. Schmidt to delay this, as I thought we should at least start on our own and, if things go well, we could keep on manufacturing without the necessity of such a loan. In any case, you will hear of this later.

Please accept my thanks and my very sincere appreciation for all that has been done by you personally and by your Department towards the setting up of this industry among the Indians which I hope will be a success. I have no doubt in the world it will be unless some day unexpected difficulties arise. We shall keep you posted of the progress of this initiative. The Bishop who is very interested, is now working with me to prepare location for this instalment. The machinery has not yet arrived.

Thanking you once again, I remain,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

P.S.- Mr. A. Gagnon, Loretteville, is not by any means a wealthy man, and I am sure he would appreciate the payment of his equipment at the earliest possible date.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Mr. Nelson has turned over to us the Electrical Plant your Department has been so good as to purchase us and we feel perfectly satisfied with it. He has overhauled it and I am sure we have a very good piece of equipment. We have not set it up yet as it is too cold to build the cement foundation that it requires. We will do this as soon as we can however. We have purchased a small building for our Plant and we are to move it here very shortly.

I wish to thank you very heartily for this very valuable donation, Mr. Hoey, and all those who have helped in securing it for us. It will mean a great deal for our enterprise and our community. We will certainly try to justify your efforts in helping us by keeping on the work we have started and which I still believe will prove to be one of the best means to civilize our natives.

We are working steadily though we are not producing in huge quantities. We cannot produce in big volumes. We have not the capital for this purpose. We are forced to buy in relatively small quantities and therefore our output must be in line with our purchases. We are moving ahead however.

To-night, in a general meeting, we will fill out forms, a memorandum of association for the erection of a Credit Union in Grouard, among the Indians. I think the time has come for that institution too. We have been having classes at night treating this subject. The people are very willing to co-operate. They realize a little better now, that saving is the only way out of their destitution. They have deposited quite a little money already and they promise to do more. As soon as we have officially opened the doors of this institution, I shall give you more information.

Once again, I thank you very heartily and

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

After having filled the form sent to me by your department according to the best of my knowledge, I make up my mind to put a few additional words in this letter, as to let you know more clearly whether or not I have the required capacity of being the Instructor for the Indian Boys in this Vocational School.

My little experience with or in touch with the School Boys dates from 35 years. This started exactly in 1907. From that time I had very often some Boys working with me after school time and during their free hours. This was always quite a work, like farm work as well as house work. We used to work also with engines and also occasionally with further, cooking fuel for stock, making flour for about a month a year... and many other kind of work we have to have with here and there. From 1916 I worked mostly in the general shop work with some Boys coming to be trained for many hours a week. I tried to teach the Boys according my knowledge in the wood work which does not consist in anything really or purely technical or expensive but of something practical and really useful in every house or on every farm and specially among the Indian people.

The last year 1924 before June the Boys had performed the following things in the Shop: 4 or 5 night cupboard which they call also wash stand, with 2 shelves and a drawer in each one, 4 kitchen and family tables, 2 radio tables, 8 cabinet or Medicine Cup board with mirror or picture on the door, 3 big chairs, 3 or 4 stools, 2 big loan of garden Benches, 2 wall shelves close special for Indian houses, 5 strong little wagons for children playing off, 3 little toboggans for children playing, 2 wheel barrows, and many hobbies.

(see over)
made by the beginners which is too long to be listed.

Besides the big boys have many occupations not only in the wood work also in the tin work, farm implements repairing, as handling axes, forks, hoes, and even other tools eventually.

In the spring time I use to take care of a garden which also is attended by all the boys. This work consists of sowing, thinning, weeding, transplanting etc., etc. The boys use to show a real interest in this work, and as a result, the heavy crop in the fall has often given evidence that the work and trouble was not scattered in vain.

If you wish me to give you any other data of my little experience with the Indian Boys, please let me know about it, and I will be pleased making my best also in this regard.

Sincerely Yours,

Brother T. Nicol.

Re: Grouard Indian School, Alta.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

As nobody asked me for making any kind of report about the Boys training in the woodwork during the season ending June 30th, 46, I put in mind to make here a short statement of what the Boys have performed in the Shop during the time past away.

The boys came to the shop in two groups, one of the groups included 5 boys, some of them came to work for the third year, some of them for the second. The other group where only 4 boys, all of them except one came to the shop the first time.

The conduct of the boys, in general, was satisfactorily, and if some ones eventually did not show a full interest, yet the most part of them gave a good application to their work and consequently showed also a real betterment from the previous years.

The boys have only made during the year what is absolutely utilities for the houses, farms, and around the barns, because as these Indian boys are already as big as ordinary Men and liable (at least for one part), not to come to school anymore, it is advisable to teach them to do what they are going to need in their own house tomorrow, also I use to ask every boy before they begin one project to ponder which item they need or like more to have in their house or on their "so-called" farm. The answer is nearly always what is really useful for any house and much more for every Indian houses, which use mostly to be empty from wall to wall.

The following citations will give you a short account of the articles made by the nine boys this year: The number of the pieces stamped by myself before the two-weeks exhibition at the end of the year amounted to about 87 pieces.

Children cribs, 7; Kitchen and family tables, 7; utility cupboard, 8; general utility trunks, 6; chairs with elbow-rest, 12; other chairs, 5; Lawn benches 6 feet long, 2; Medicine cabinet, 8; Stools, 7. Besides this, they have also made (around the spring time), many bird houses, guns, many wagons, (toys), and also bigger wagons, which they use around the houses for hauling kitchen wood, etc. Many other things are not quoted here. I add only some tool carriers, many flower stands.

Of these many things stated here above, I was pleased to find, the Principal of this school graciously willing (in spite of quite many expenses to support the shop in boards, planks, nails, screws, paints, etc., to give to each boy, off the shop-work, two of the best pieces they have performed during the year, two pieces to their own choice, this was a gracious revelation for the parents and also a "start-pieces", of desirable ambition for having later-on, yet more furniture in their houses which will also contribute in some extend to the improvement of their welfare.

The boys
The boys of the second and third year have also made many pieces of metal work, as scoops, dust-pans, repairing and soldering.

They have made a garden and although under my supervision, they have themselves lined, planted, covered and cared of until the time of their going for vacations, and I ascertain that actually we are not ashamed to show to the welcome visitors the "Boys Garden".

Any remarks you would make to me about this letter which is made in any way of a little report, or any other advice for the future, would be received with thanks.

Sincerely yours,

Brother T. Nicol, O.M.I.,
Instructor,
Grouard Indian School,
Grouard Mission P.O.,

March 23/43

Gravesh, Alta.

Dear Mr. Chelan,

I was given to understand at the Indian School Convention last fall that the Dept. would send me a number of goats for milking.

I have been thanking on them considerably and would like to know if it is still your intention to send me some, what number, if they will be milking at the time and about when you expect they will come. I am ready for them and promise you to make good in the results.

Thank you kindly,

Yours truly,

Rev. G. Forester
Ottawa,
April 5, 1943.

Mr. C.F. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Grouard Residential School requesting us to supply them with goats. At several of the Indian residential schools in Eastern Canada we have started goat herds with satisfactory results and we would like to see some of these herds encouraged at some of the residential schools in Alberta. With special reference to the recent request from the Grouard Residential School, I would appreciate your advising if you can obtain 6 female goats and 1 male goat in your province. An early reply would be appreciated stating where you can secure the goats and their cost.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Calgary, April 28th, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, OTTAWA.

Reference your No. 131-1-11 of the 5th instant re purchasing six (6) female and one male goats for the Grouard Indian Residential School, I beg to say that I have made enquiries and have not found anything suitable in the Southern part of the Province. It would appear that the greatest number of the few herds that were in the South were sold a short time ago for use on the bombing range (see experimental work) at Suffield, Alta., near Medicine Hat.

In company with Mr. S.G. Freeborn, Senior Live Stock Field Man for the Dominion Department of Agriculture, Room 411 Public Building, Calgary, we looked over two lots in the outskirts of Calgary, but did not find any females that would be worth buying. We saw a two-year old Toggenburg Buck which could be used providing females of the same breed or species can be found. This animal is well bred (good blood line), but apparently has not had proper care and attention, and therefore has not developed as well as he should have. We were unable to get a price on this animal, which belongs to Mrs. Grace Court, now of Vancouver, B.C. The owner who is keeping the animal says she will demand a high price. He is most anxious that she get rid of the animal which he claims is very cross and vicious, and has to be kept in a pen or tethered.

Edmonton District:

Through the office of the Edmonton Exhibition Association, Ltd., I was informed that Mr. J.J. Thompson, 11143 - 106 Street, Edmonton, has a number of female goats, ages two to six years, some of which are fresh, and others due to freshen soon. His price ranges from $20.00 to $35.00 each. The name of the breed was not given.

Mr. W.H.T. Mead, Live Stock Promoter, Provincial Department of Agriculture, informs me that Mr. N.S. Thompson of 8550 - 74th Ave., Edmonton, has six female goats to sell, for $30.00 each, all bred and to freshen soon. These are of the Saanen breed. He has no male animals to sell.

Mr. G.C. Leight, Indian Agent, Winterburn, informs me that Mr. G.A. Johnson, 9555 - 103A Ave., Edmonton, has six female goats and a buck, ages one to three years, for which he is asking $155.00.

I have just been informed that a Mr. Henry Guenette, 11210 53rd Street, Edmonton, had a few young goats; however these may have been disposed of; I have not communicated with him.

Agent L'Heureux writes that he does not know anyone in the Grouard district who has goats for sale.

From information I can gather, a fairly well bred female -- two to three years old -- with a flow of two quarts or better of milk, is worth about $25.00 to $40.00. Prices are higher than they were two or three years ago.

If a buck cannot be found in Alberta I would suggest buying a buck kid in British Columbia, to be shipped to Grouard when weaned. He would be ready for service next Winter.

(over)

In conversation with Mr. S.G. Freeborn, aforementioned, who is known as the "Goat Man for Canada" he stated that he would be quite willing to take charge of the purchase of these seven (7) goats for us, and arrange shipment to Grouard. I recommend that this be done; personally I have never had anything to do with goats. It might be well for our Branch to take up with Mr. R.S. Homer, Director of Production Service, Department of Agriculture, Ottawa, the matter of having Mr. Freeborn make the purchase for us on his first trip to the Edmonton district.

C. Pant. Schmidt,

Re: Purchase of Goats,
Grouard Residential School.

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 28 and to thank you for the information contained therein.

We are of the opinion, from our experience in the East, that the Saanen breed of goat is the best adapted for use at our residential schools. This is a dairy type of goat, with a milk supply averaging about one gallon per goat per day.

We are interested in the goats at present the property of G. A. Johnson, 9555 - 103 A. Avenue, Edmonton. If these goats are a good breed and are in a healthy condition, we do not consider the price of $155.00 excessive. Would it be possible to have Mr. Freeborn inspect these goats at the time of his visit to Edmonton? The actual purchase could be made by Indian Agent Laight. We would like these goats purchased at as early a date as possible.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Miss Blanchfield;

I have received your letter of the 8th re goats and called at Mr. G. A. Johnson's home, 9555, 103rd Ave. this evening but he was not at home. However, I spoke to him on the phone (his number is 21406) and he tells me that he has disposed of some of the females but knows where he can get others to replace. He still has the billy goat.

Would you please call on Mr. S. G. Freeborn and if he comes to Edmonton (say next week) he could call Mr. Johnson on the phone and arrange to see the goats immediately. Mr. Johnson has a car. It is five miles to the farm. If these goats are not suitable, (note what Mr. Hoey says regarding breed "Saanen") he could see the others mentioned in my letter to Mr. Hoey (copy of which I enclose herewith together with Mr. Hoey's letter).

As regards price, he can be governed by Mr. Hoey's letter, i.e., 7 at $155.00 is not considered excessive. ($155.00 ÷ 7 = $22.15) I do not want to suggest an average price. Mr. Freeborn knows more about this than I do and I know that he will select good milk producers. When he has found suitable animals, I would ask him to kindly contact Mr. G. C. Laight who will make the actual purchase and submit the voucher. Mr. Freeborn will, I am sure, advise him of any precaution or arrangements, if any, to be made in the Railway car.

I understand that Mr. Johnson expects to leave on a trip East before the end of the month.

Yours Truly,

Reference Mr. Hoey's letter No. 131-1-14 of the 3rd ultimo, copy of which Miss Blanchfield sent me while I was in Edmonton, I beg to enclose herewith copy of my letter dated at Edmonton on May 12th, 1943, addressed to Miss Blanchfield, which is self-explanatory.

Mr. Freeborn was contacted, and it was arranged that he and Indian Agent G.C. Leight of Winterburn would go together to see the goats. Mr. Freeborn's report on this matter reads as follows:

"Calgary, June 2, 1943.

"Dear Mr. Schmidt,

"In connection with the milk goats required for the Grouard Residential School, I contacted the Indian Agent at Winterburn, Mr. G.C. Leight, and we first got in touch with Mr. A.A. Johnson, 9555 - 103A Ave., Edmonton, and in company with him visited half a dozen prospects. Afterwards we contacted Mr. J.J. Thompson, 11143 - 106th St., and went from there to Mr. N.S. Thompson, of 8550 - 74th Ave., Edmonton. I also checked up on Mr. C. Scott who has quite a number of goats in the neighborhood of 155th St. and 106th Ave., and Mr. Frank Adamson, 82nd Ave. and 80th St.

"We could not find anything that I would care to recommend for the Grouard purchase. Apparently the younger goats have been pretty well picked over, and the only goats of suitable size, type, quality and character were goats from five to eight years of age. While we could purchase five or six old goats that, properly mated with a good buck, might be expected to produce fair grade milk goat kids, I was of the opinion that for a foundation flock such as the Grouard Residential School would be expecting, an average age of six to seven years was too much of a handicap.

"The best goats were in the hands of Mr. N.S. Thompson, Mr. Frank Adamson and Mr. J.J. Thompson. Mr. N.S. Thompson informed me that he had just one yearling doe in kid but not freshened yet that would be of the general character that we might require. She was out on his farm elsewhere and it was raining hard so we did not inspect this individual.

"Mr. N.S. Thompson also informed me that the goats that he previously offered for sale were snapped up very quickly. He directed us to Frank Adamson if we could use old goats, giving the old goats that Adamson had for sale a good recommendation.

"I regret that we were unable to locate the making of a herd that would promise satisfaction, but I do think that a herd of this kind should not average more

In conversation with Mr. Freeborn at this office today, he informs me that he does not know where he can find any young goats that will be suitable for our purpose; and that in the aged class -- 5 to 8 years of age -- he probably could have obtained 6 animals, but of this number one only would have been five years of age. Re: Establishment of Goat Herd - Grouard Indian Residential School.

Reference Departmental letter No. 131-1-14 of the 4th instant, I beg to report that I proceeded to Vancouver, where in company with Mr. T.G. Stewart, Dominion Live Stock Fieldman, we drove out to the owners' homes to look over the goats offered, which I found to be very nice animals; -- all white, with fine coats of hair, sound of limb, and very tame and easy to handle. Four of these had kidded a few days before, giving male kids, which were destroyed; the owners have not the grass in their very small holdings to rear non-productive goats; their interest is in milk-producing animals only.

I was very much impressed with the udders of these goats, i.e., the size of them: They were giving 2, 3 and 4 quarts, and are not yet up to their full flow of milk; they are still young.

One is due to freshen in March, and the other two are due some time in April; these, with the four mentioned in the first paragraph of this letter, make up a total of seven (7).

There was one thing which I wanted to find out first-hand for myself, viz., whether these goats were specially cared for, groomed, and what they were fed; or, in other words, whether they were pampered like some dairy cows: I found that this was not the case. They are out in the open, with a shed which they can enter if it is stormy and snowing. As regards feed, they are given a small feed of chop (oat hulls mostly) and a bit of green feed. As for grazing, their small plots are cropped very close. I was glad to see this condition, because they cannot get worse anywhere, and at the Grouard School they will be properly stabled and well fed.

Mr. Stewart will arrange for shipping (in individual crates) sometime around the 15th of March. This will give the animals that have already freshened time to pick up stamina for the trip, and those that do not come in till April will have time to rest and get familiar with their new surroundings and the people who handle them.

We have not been very successful to date with the goats which the Department of Indian Affairs had sent us for the well-being of the Indians.

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, August 1, 1944.

Mr. C. P. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alberta.

I have for acknowledgment copies of correspondence relating to the goats purchased a few months ago by the Department for use at the Grouard Residential School.

The purchase of these goats represented an attempt to provide the Indian pupils in attendance at the school with a certain amount of training in the care and feeding of these animals. We have been assured from time to time by nutritionists, particularly by Dr. Kruse, of the Milbank Foundation, New York, that it is almost impossible to provide a balanced diet, particularly for children, in the absence of fresh milk. If such is the case, training in the care and feeding of goats is just as important as instruction in Reading, Writing and Arithmetic.

The objections raised by the Principal of this School are scarcely convincing. If the goats have given trouble in the destruction of trees, there is no reason whatever why they should not be fenced in or tethered. Thousands of small farmers in Europe keep goats on small plots of land, surrounded by beautiful trees. This is done by tethering and by careful supervision. The Department, however, has no desire to keep goats at a school in opposition to the wishes of the Principal. It might be well, therefore, for you to discuss the matter somewhat fully, by letter, with the Principal himself, and, if necessary, transfer these goats to another residential school in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency. If the school principals are unwilling to accept them, you might canvass the possibility of having the goats distributed to a reputable and dependable Indian family.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 6th instant and have noted with interest the somewhat disturbing information contained therein.

May I re-emphasize the fact that these goats were purchased for the Grouard Residential School in response to a number of requests for goats, received by us from the church authorities. The expenditure involved in this purchase - travelling expenses, freight on goats, purchase price, etc., was quite substantial. I feel that you, the senior administrative officer of Indian Affairs in Alberta, should inform the school authorities that this is not the kind of cooperation expected from them by the Department and that this is an experience that should not be repeated at any time in the future.

In view of all the circumstances, you are authorized to take the steps necessary to have these goats transferred to the Residential School at St. Albert. It is my hope that the Indian pupils in attendance at this school will have an opportunity to receive instruction in the general care and feeding of these animals. Ultimately, of course, we shall have to establish goat herds in the North. As a matter of fact, the Hudson's Bay Company, with years of experience behind them, are establishing a number of goat herds this year at their outlying posts. We do not deem it wise, however, to ask a school principal to keep animals in the care of which he is no longer interested.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Statement of Father PHOUIX:
"Grouard, Alberta,
Sept.15/36.

Father Marcel PHOUIX states:
About 7:30 p.m. On Sept.15/36, I was called into the boys' room by Sister Marcella. She pointed out one of the boys in bed & I felt his pulse. There was none. Artificial respiration was tried without result. I learned that the boy's name was George Big Bear, a treaty from Whitefish Lake. Sgd. Father Marcel PHOUIX

The room where the boys sleep is a large place and has 75 beds; at present there are 65 boys sleeping in the room. I was given to understand that there is always one of the Sisters present when the children are in the room, and during the night one of the Sisters sleeps in an adjoining room on the same floor, so that she is always available if necessary. On the night in question, Sister Gerard was on duty, and she advised me that there was no disturbance during the night and the boy had not complained. Neither had he been complaining since his return from Whitefish Lake about not feeling well. The Sister did notice that the boy had not been looking very well since his return to school on September 1/36, but as he appeared to be getting along alright, she did not say anything. The mother of the child resides at Whitefish Lake and a messenger was sent to notify her of the death of her child, also Mr. N.P. L'HIRURUX of DRIFTPILE who is the Indian Agent was informed of the boy's death. Statement was also obtained from Coroner McIntyre as follows:

High Prairie, Alberta,
Sept.15/36.

Statement of E.L. McIntyre, Coroner of HIGH PRAIRIE, On Sept.15/36, Corporal Faulkner and myself were notified that a boy (George Big Bear) 10 years of age had died in bed in the GROUARD CATHOLIC MISSION boys' dormitory. We proceeded by auto livery and motor boat to the R.O.M. School at Grouard, after taking statements and examining the body, I decided that the boy had died from natural causes. The body was that of a male child of about 10 years of age, fairly well developed and slightly debilitated. He had a well marked scabies condition on the body, and the pupils widely dilated, but there were no marks of violence on the body. Apparently the boy had had influenza of both respiratory and gastric intestinal type during the latter part of the holidays and he had returned to school in a debilitated condition.

(b) He also had congenital V.D.S., death had apparently been caused by heart failure (V.D.R.) from influenza; the condition had been aggravated by congenital V.D.S.; I signed the death certificate accordingly, I decided that an inquest was unnecessary.

Sgd. E.L. McIntyre, M.D."

In view of the above statement and my investigation I am concluding this case. The boy is being buried at GROUARD, death being registered before W.B. MILLER, Esq., of that point by the Rev. Father PARKER of Catholic Mission.

Attached copy of this report for Mr. L'HIRURUX of DRIFTPILE who is Indian Agent for this district.

Concluded.

Expense incurred.

Corpl.

Re: George BIG BEAR, Grouard, Alberta,
(Treaty)
Sudden Death.

Headquarters:
1. Sept. 16/36, I received a phone call from Mr. McIntyre, Coroner at HIGH PRAIRIE, that the above named boy age 10 years had been found dead in his bed at the Catholic Mission School at GROUARD, he had apparently been alright the night before, and when the Sister in charge of the room had gone around to wake the boys at 7:30 am she found him dead in bed.

2. Accompanied by Coroner McIntyre via auto livery we left HIGH PRAIRIE and patrolled to the GROUARD boat landing, where we met the ferry boat and continued our journey to GROUARD, upon arrival we were shown the body of the boy, examination of the body showed there were no marks or violence, statements were taken from the witnesses as follows:

"Grouard, Alberta,
Sept. 16/36.

George BIGBEAR states; I am 6 years of age, and a Treaty Indian my mother resides at WHITEFISH LAKE where she is still living, my other George (Deceased) spent our vacation at WHITEFISH and returned to school on the 1st of Sept. 1936. George was about 10 years of age.

(b) About July 1/36, my brother & I left school & went to WHITEFISH LAKE, my brother was in good health at that time, after he had been home for about two weeks he took sick, he had headaches and vomiting spells, he was sick for a long time at home, he would get up to eat his meals and go right back to bed again."

"Grouard, Alberta,
Sept. 16/36.

Sister Mary AUXILIATRICE states:
I am in charge of the boys room at the Catholic Mission at Grouard, George & Gordon Big Bear arrived from Whitefish Lake about Sept. 1/36, for school.

(b) George ate well, but he was pale & thin when he came back to school, I was not on duty this morning.

Sister Mary Auxiliatrice."

"Grouard, Alberta,
Sept. 16/36.

Sister Paul GERARD states:
The boy (George BIGBEAR) was feeling fine when he left school for vacation, coming back in September he was pale and then this morning waking the boy up I found the boy dead, I called him by name but no answer so I felt his pulse, and heart beat and could not find any sign of life, the boy appeared to be better the night before even better than usual, he was not sick during the night.

(Sgd., Sr. Paul GERARD)

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively; and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is obtained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pagin'g it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered in the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The annual per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column, under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Ottawa, October 22nd, 1919.

Reverend Sir,

The September quarter grant of the St. Brune Boarding school is being paid on an average attendance of 50 pupils and amounts to $1612.50. From this amount a deduction of $60.00, for supplies purchased by the school from the Militia Department, is being made and a cheque for the balance, $1752.50, is being sent you.

**PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA**
Ottawa, August 4, 1931.

Right Reverend Sir:

With reference to that portion of your letter of the 10th ultimo, requesting advances on the September quarter grants of certain Indian residential schools, I beg to say that arrangements are being made to make the following advances on the September quarter earnings:

- St. Bernard's - $2,000.
- Vermilion - 1,500.
- Wabasca - 1,800.
- Sturgeon Lake - 2,000.
- St. Bruno's - 3,000.

Total: $10,300.

It is hoped to send a cheque for the above amount about the end of this week. The cheque will be drawn in favour of the Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Grouard and sent to the Banque Canadienne Nationale, Jasper Avenue, Edmonton, Alta.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Right Rev. Joseph Guy, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Grouard,
Grouard, Alta.
St. Paul's Hospital

Vancouver, B.C.

August 29, 1931.

Mr. R.T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

Your kind letter of August the 4th duly received together with amount of $10,300, which it was announcing.

Please receive our best thanks, as this advance is at the present time of great advantage for our work.

Yours very truly,

Vicar Apostolic of Grouard.

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE.

W. REGINA, SASK., 28th February, 1934

Re: St. Bruno Residential School
Joussard, Alta. R/C

Dear Mr. Allen:

While at the Lesser Slave Lake Agency, I drove to the above Indian School on February 23rd in order to examine the books and report thereon.

The Indian Agent introduced me to the Principal, Reverend C. Falher, O.M.I., and upon enquiring as to the finances and records, the Principal informed me that he had no books at the school nor did he handle the grant or make any expenditures.

It appears that Bishop Guy at Grouard handles the grants and finances on behalf of some five residential schools in this northern Alberta diocese which is distinct from the Diocese of Edmonton and St. Boniface in Manitoba.

As Grouard is some 35 miles west and north of Driftpile at the extreme end of Lesser Slave Lake and travelling by road this time of year would be difficult, I did not make the trip, as I considered the Department would not wish me to spend the time or expense in so doing. From the conversation with Father Falher I gathered that Bishop Guy had taken up the matter of auditing with the Department.

Grouard is fifteen miles from railhead, the train service from Driftpile is twice weekly and there was a possibility of Bishop Guy being away, in which event I would be unable to learn very much regarding the records etc.

This for your information.

Yours faithfully,

H. B. Rayner,
Auditor.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, February 25, 1936.

Dear Sir:

At the request of His Lordship Bishop Guy, the Department is approving, as from April first, next, a change in the name of two Indian Residential Schools in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency, conducted under the auspices of His Lordship, as follows:

St. Bernard's Indian Residential School to be changed to ORQUARD

St. Bruno's Indian Residential School to be changed to JOUSSARD

In future, in all official correspondence, you should refer to each of these schools by the new name, as given above.

Mr. Agent L'Heureux is being informed.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

M. Christianson, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Calgary, Alta.

Grouard, Alta., Nov. 26th, 1940.

Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Re: Advances on December term.

I take the liberty of requesting the Department to make me an advance on the December quarter grants. My ambition is to clear as many bills as possible before the end of the calendar year.

I would appreciate receiving the following amount:

1) On Grouard School: $2,500.00
2) On Jeussard: $2,500.00
3) On Wabasca School: $2,500.00
4) On Sturgeon Lake School: $2,000.00
5) On Fort Vermilion School: $1,500.00

$11,000.00

Thanking you in advance for the sympathetic attention you will give to this request,

I remain,

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Yours very truly,

F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.
