Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief Training Division,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa ONT.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

The entrance of the children from the two reserves of Driftpile and Sucker Creek, to Joussard Indian Residential School, had been fixed as at September 2nd by Mr. Landry, Indian Agent. However, due to an epidemic of measles on the Sucker Creek Reserve, the date has been delayed to September 14th and even later, if found necessary.

Will you please advise me if in the trimestrial report of September, I should mention the absence of the children on account of illness, and if the grant will be allowed in this case - as for the vacation period, (July and August). In a similar case at Grouard a few years ago, I remember that the grant was not discontinued for the month of September.

Thanking you in anticipation, and with kind personal regards, I remain,

Yours very truly,

Joseph Habay, O.M.I.,
Principal

JH/BL.
Ottawa, September 16th, 1947.

Dear Father Habay:

We have your letter of the 1st instant in which you advise that owing to illness on the reserve, several children from Driftpile and Sucker Creek will not return to Joussard for some weeks.

We regret this situation but we cannot see our way clear to allow grant when children are absent. Consequently, when preparing the September quarter return grant should be requested for those children who were in the school on June 30th and who have not returned owing to illness for 62 days (holiday leave), plus the actual number of days such pupils may be in residence during the September quarter. A note should appear opposite each of them stating the reason for their absence.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. Joseph Habay, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Joussard Indian Res. School,
Joussard, Alberta.

Ottawa, November 13, 1947.

Mr. A. Landry, Indian Agent, High Prairie, Alberta.

With reference to the attached September Quarter Return of the Joussard Indian Residential School, it is requested that you draw the Principal's attention to the fact that children who are not in Residential Schools for the full quarter should have an explanation and the dates of their absence shown opposite their names. It is also noted that numerous pupils have not returned due to neglect on the part of the parents. Please inform us what action has been taken in stopping the Family Allowance to their parents.

We are forwarding a part payment to the La Corporation Episcopale C.R. de Grouard, McLennan, Alberta, in order that the delayed payment of this Return will not cause undue financial inconvenience.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Encl:
KB/HH.
February 4, 1948.

Mr. A. Landry, Indian Agent,
High Prairie, Alberta.

I desire to refer you to official letter of November 13th, 1947, with which we sent back the September quarter return of the Joussard Indian Residential School. In that letter we requested that the return be reviewed and amended where necessary.

Recently we received the December quarter return but the principal has not yet sent back to us the September quarter return. Grant for December cannot be paid until we receive the September return.

Please arrange to have this forwarded to us immediately.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

PP/MGD
February 26, 1948.

Dear Father Beuglet:

The Department found it necessary to send back the September quarter return of the Joussard Indian Residential School as it had not been properly prepared. This return was sent to Indian Agent Landry on November 13, 1947.

At the end of December we received the December quarter return but we could not pay the grant for that quarter due to the fact that we had not received the September quarter return.

I would appreciate it if you would arrange with the principal of the Joussard Residential School to complete his September quarter return and send it to the Department by air mail so that the amount due for September and December can be paid.

It will interest you to know that the per capita allowance has been increased by 17%, effective from October 1st, 1947.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Rev. L. Beuglet, O.M.I.,
McLennan, Alberta.

Extract from Mr. Inspector Yule's Report on the
St. BRUNO BOARDING SCHOOL. April 9, 1923.

Previous information indicated that there
were only two rooms at this mission. A third room was
established. This room is not properly equipped with
seats and desks. Long tables and forms are used with
children facing each other. It is not a suitable class
room arrangement. Proper seating accommodation should be
provided.

L. B. Yule,
Insp.
Sir:

The report of the Public School Inspector who visited the St. Bruno's Boarding School in April, 1925, has been received by the Department. In his report he draws attention to the need of proper equipment for the third classroom which has been established at this school. He states that at present the room is not properly equipped with seats and desks - long tables and forms being used, with the children facing each other, which is not a suitable classroom arrangement.

The Department would be favourably disposed to providing single desks sufficient for the requirements of this third classroom; but, before doing so, it will be necessary to ascertain the sizes of the desks needed and the number of each size. For the information of yourself and the principal, I beg to say that single desks are made suitable for children of the following ages:

- Ages 5 to 7 years,
- Ages 7 to 9 years,
- Ages 10 to 12 years,
- Ages 12 to 14 years,
- Ages 15 to 18 years

Kindly consult the principal and inform the Department the number of desks that would be needed to suit the children between the above ages. As soon as we have this information, we will be in a position to place an order here for the desks. You should also give full shipping directions. Kindly attend to this matter at your earliest convenience.

I may further add that, if any blackboards are required for this extra classroom, the same will be supplied if the dimensions are given - that is both the length and breadth.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

H. Laird, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Grouard, Alta.

Dear Sir,

It is my sad duty to inform you that fire has destroyed St. Bruno's Boarding School. This unhappy accident occurred on December 26th, it was a Sunday, the children had been called to church, nobody was in the building and no warning could be given early enough to stop the fire.

My contract with the government was that I had to build the schools at my own expense, a somewhat larger grant perhaps being allowed for housing children. Twenty years ago this country was still closed to civilization and the government found it a little hard to build our schools. Presently conditions are changed. The Edmonton-Prince Albert railway passes at 3 miles from St. Bruno Village. The task of rebuilding the school is so great for me that I humbly pray the government to undertake the work.

We have about 90 children here and we expect to have 100 more. All the Indians of Little River Lake belong to the Roman Catholic Church and besides the children who have their parents, numerous orphans are to be cared for. Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

The St. Bruno's Indian Residential School had two large buildings, a principal's residence and some smaller structures. The building operations were during the years 1913 to 1914; the property was church-owned.

The Indian agent reports that the main building has been burned and immediately we have filled rush requisitions for school, etc., I believe it was the boys' building, in which were the classrooms that was lost. Mr. Lordship's letter states that the St. Bruno's Residential School has been destroyed and it may be that the other large building or the girls' wing has also been burned; but from the information that is now at hand I believe that only one of the large buildings was lost.

This building had three classrooms and the boys' dormitories. His Lordship states that the girls are being cared for with the Sisters in the girls' building, I believe, as the Sisters' quarters were in this structure) and that the boys are living in the principal's residence.

For two years the school has earned the maximum grant of $60 and there are on the roll at present $4. The Bishop states there were about 90 children at the time of the fire.

Thirty-nine boys are now crowded into the principal's residence and the accommodation in the girls' building will be much too small as classroom facilities will have to be found. Hence, without doubt, the situation is urgent and a great number of these pupils are orphaned without homes and cannot be sent away. A building with three classrooms and proper residential facilities for 60 boys should be erected at the first opportunity. The Government does not own any Indian residential schools north of Edmonton and Saddle Lake, but the opening up of the Croward territory and the presence of a railway station three miles from the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School suggests that the time has arrived for the Department to consider capital expense.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

With reference to the attached letter from His Lordship the Bishop of Athabasca, I have to inform you that the main building at the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School, near Crowfoot, Alta., will have to be replaced without delay. This institution had more than the average number of orphan children and the authorities will be in serious difficulty if the main building is not rebuilt as soon as the building season opens. I have discussed this problem with Rev. Father C. Falher, the business manager for the Diocese, who is at present in Ottawa, and I am pleased to report that the Oblate Fathers will rebuild if the Department will assist. Rough sketches of the proposed building are being made by the Department Architect and he has provided the church representative with a list of the materials required.

I wish to recommend that His Lordship be asked to rebuild at the first opportunity and that the Department promise a grant of £15,000 for the purpose, if they will erect a building which conforms to the specifications laid down by us. A frame structure of three stories, 80 ft. by 40 ft., wired for electricity and heated by two hot air furnaces, will be in keeping with the other buildings at the school and will be suitable for this locality. The Church will be put to an expense of roughly £1,000 and the Department has funds available in the appropriation for Indian Education for a grant of £12,000 this fiscal year. His Lordship will have to prepare a declaration concerning his expenditures for materials which can be purchased immediately and he can support such declaration with receipted accounts for at least the amount of our grant.

Father Guy wired His Lordship the Bishop of Athabasca, at my request, for advice as to how we could help and I was referred to Father Falher, who concurs in the arrangement I have outlined.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

St. Bruno Mission,
Oct. 25 - 1929

Mr. Harvey Orr, Architect
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Orr -

In a letter addressed to you about the end of January, we had mentioned the necessity of having storm windows for the old building as well as the new one.

Having received no specifications whatever in connection with the plans sent for the new wing being built, we are somewhat at a loss as to whether certain articles have been granted or not. Could you enlighten us on the subject? The cold weather coming on would necessitate the use of storm windows soon. We had also mentioned having screens for convenience as well as protection sake, but have had no answer concerning this either.

I hope I am not putting you to any inconvenience in asking you this, so many little things come up every day that I seem to be continually putting in a demand for something.

There are 65 windows in the old building and all would need storm windows.

The new wing is progressing
rapidly, and will serve as a fitting monument, doing honor to the generosity and big-heartedness of our Ottawa friends and benefactors.

Hoping to hear from you by return-mail, I remain,

Yours very gratefully,
Sister Mary Athlone
Superior

Dear Mr. Scott,

You will no doubt be interested in the progress of the work being done on the new wing. The plumbing is well advanced, most of the tiling finished, and the plum-fitters have arrived today to begin their work. The contractor announced today also that the needed alterations in the old house would begin immediately after the Christmas holidays; which means that we will have to take possession of a few rooms in the new wing most likely the class-rooms. I am enclosing a little snap-shot which will give you a little idea of its appearance, later on we will have a better one to show you.

The cold weather has arrived and caught me unawares, we having forty below zero weather just now and find it hard to keep warm. Seems to be continually asking for something, Mr. Scott, but it seems that if we had storm windows on the old building,
it would be so much easier to heat the house. We mentioned this when we sent in the plans, but no answer was given as to whether they had been granted or not. The storm windows are all on, on the new wing, and it makes such a difference for heating. We would need 6' x 2' pane windows 8 by 12 for the old house. If they have been granted we should be pleased to know it as soon as possible, so that this may not be delayed too long.

I am making out the list of needed furniture for the different apartments as I mentioned in a recent letter and will forward it soon, for your approval.

My requests are many, it seems, but I should like to have everything just as you would have it. I am sure if you were to hear my many demands, if, however, any of these things seem unnecessary to your board of being, you have only to say so, the refusal will be well accepted.

Looking to hear from you shortly regarding my new request.

Yours very sincerely,

Jussard, Alta.

Revd. Sir,

During my recent visit to St. Bruno's Mission I took the liberty of looking over your lighting plant. I am very sorry you were not home so that we could have discussed the matter together as I believe you will find it necessary to increase the capacity of your plant to take care of new building. Your present engine is of an old type and has seen much service and has reached that stage when it cannot be depended upon for heavier work. It is of the gravity feed type with low tension ignition necessitating batteries and coil for starting and is getting much the worse for wear. It is not necessary for me to point out to you the inconvenience and possible danger of the lighting system in an institution such as you have at St. Bruno. The generator would be overloaded during your peak load which would make the whole outfit unreliable.

I would recommend not less than a 6 K.W. plant and can give you the following styles at prices mentioned:

- 6 K.W. Lister-Bruston Automatic 110 Volt less Batteries $2389.00
- 6 K.W. Lister Non-Automatic " " " " $1700.00

Unskilled help to be also provided by you and necessary base to be provided in suitable place in accordance with blue prints before arrival of expert for installation.

I have not included batteries in above prices as your present batteries are in first class condition and will serve you for several years. It would give me pleasure to discuss this matter further with you or if you decide to change I can promise you prompt and satisfactory service.

Honorable Sir,

Another difficult problem has presented itself this week and I hasten to lay it before you, being totally unable to contend with it myself.

It seems as if there is no end to these particular needs, and just when we think one has been satisfied another one comes up.

Our lighting plant having been out of order, we were obliged to call in the electrician who afterwards wrote the enclosed letter to Mr. Father Thross. I can truthfully corroborate this statement of his, for since we are having extra lights in the new building our shop aims to be constantly out of order. Although having no knowledge of lighting plants, I did not think at the time that it was caused by the lack of power.

Now, you will see by Mr. Father Thross' letter the real estate of things and I do not in the least doubt of your capability in arranging it to the satisfaction of all and the advantage of the school.

Work has begun in the old building, and preparations are in full swing.

We are gladly putting up with the many inconveniences this causes us.
joining in the fact that we will soon be comfortably settled in our pretty new home.

Last week we had the pleasure of Mr. Scott's visit. He was delighted with the improvements and said it surpassed his expectations in convenience and beauty. Numerous visitors have come lately and all are amazed to find such a mansion in the far North. We do not hesitate to give you all the credit for it dear Mr. Scott and are glad of every opportunity to speak loudly of your kindness for our Indian missions.

You cannot imagine, however, Sir, what a load of responsibility it takes from my shoulders to know that I can rely on you entirely to straighten out these problems which seem to come daily. The promptness with which you comply with so many demands makes me feel that I need not be afraid of coming again knowing full well that you will always arrange matters for the best.

I am also sending you the list of furniture needed for each apartment.

Resting considerably upon the words "ask and you shall receive," I thank you for past favors and beg to remain,

Your very gratefully,
Sister Mary Gilbert.

A Bruni's Residential School,
Journeay,

The plumbers are leaving today so they have done all they can do till the water is in. The steam fitters are nearing the end of their task too until the powerhouse is built. Father Giroux desired us to move the children into the new house within the next few weeks. Though we are eager to have them enjoy the comfort, conveniences and the invaluable training which this would mean, still we cannot bring ourselves to move them now when such a thing would mean the carrying of water in pails to the top floor for use in dormitories and other

In September you approved of the plan of the carpenters building tables and benches when they were unable to work on the building. Ottawa, March 14, 1930.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 7th instant with reference to the proposed water-supply system for the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to advise you that the installation of a satisfactory water-supply system for this school is under consideration. The matter has been referred to the Dominion Water Power Branch and the Department is awaiting a report from the Commissioner of Irrigation at Calgary. Until this report is received and the possibility of a satisfactory water-supply system is established no action can be taken in the matter.

Yours faithfully,

(Minister's signature)

J. P. Fitzgerald, Esq.,
9550 Jasper Avenue,
Edmonton, Alberta.
March 11th, 1930.

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Sirs:

We understand that you are going to install some Laundry Equipment in the new Indian School which is at St. Bruno Mission, Indiana, Northern Alberta.

We were requested by the Heating Contractor to furnish him with prices but since that time we have been advised that the Department will probably buy the Laundry Equipment direct.

We would appreciate it if you would advise us definitely in this regard, therefore, and state if we should submit prices to your Department in Ottawa.

Thanking you in anticipation,

Yours very truly,

STANLEY BROCK LIMITED.

Manager.

WESTERN REPRESENTATIVES.

WC/S.
CC: C.L.M.Co.
Winnipeg Office.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6367, file 762-5, part 2)
Dear Dr. Scott,

In further reference to your letter of the 6th instant regarding a report on the proposed water supply system for the St. Bruno Indian Residential school, I wired to the Commissioner of Irrigation at Calgary as soon as your letter was received asking him to make a definite recommendation on this matter as soon as possible. The Commissioner wired in reply that a report would be mailed in a few days recommending an expenditure for water supply and fire protection at approximately $14,000.

I have today received an interim report on this subject, copy of which is enclosed, outlining the works required for the domestic water supply and fire protection of this school.

The Commissioner states that plans are now being prepared in his office together with an estimate and that these will be submitted at an early date so that the work can be proceeded with as soon as the approval of the Indian Department has been obtained.

The Commissioner states that he does not think it would be desirable in this case to call for tenders and considers that the best method to follow would be to give the work to Mr. Towers, who was contractor on the Onion Lake school work and Ile a la Crosse Hospital, on a cost plus basis.

I will communicate with you again as soon as further information is received from the Commissioner.

Yours very truly,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

Dr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Per M. F. C.
Commissioner of Irrigation,
Calgary, Alberta.

Sir,

Reference the investigation of a suitable water supply for the St. Bruno Indian School in the NW¼ of sec. 8, tp. 74, rge. 13, west 5th meridian, near Jousard, Alta.

I am forwarding under separate cover the following:

1. Blue-prints of the new building together with the alteration and installing of heating and plumbing fixtures in the old building.

2. Profile of ground line over proposed pipeline from the lake to the new boiler room (not built as yet).

3. General and detail plans to accompany this report, in order that proper plans may be prepared.

The first matter under consideration was selecting a site for an intake at the lake. Depths were taken at places all along the frontage of the school bounds within reason, and it was found that the lake was very shallow near the school. Many holes were cut other than those shown on the plan, until it was found that the site which is shown on the plan was the best location that could be obtained. It was expected that some eight or ten feet of water would be obtained fairly close to the shore if locating was carried out to the east of the school, and the Rev. Father Giroux loaned me a fisherman who was conversant with the lake around this vicinity. The site selected was produced into the lake for 1,800 feet, in order to determine if any banks would intervene in low stages of the lake which should, however, be discontinued as the lake is in a fairly low stage this fall and winter.

A pump house can be located immediately on top of the well defined bank where the pipeline comes out of the lake, and the floor of the pump house would be about twenty-four feet above the present water level and about thirty-five feet above the bottom of the well.

It will be observed from a study of the profile that the bed of the lake rises at station 6 ¼ 70 to station 7 ¼ 20 and is more shallow than closer to the bank.

It is proposed that the pipeline should be carried out to about station 3 ¼ 00 if that be deemed sufficient; otherwise, it will have to be carried out to station 9 ¼ 00 with a trench constructed to lower it over the hump between stations 6 ¼ 00 and station 8 ¼ 00.

In connection with this pipeline into the lake it must be recorded that great ice shoves occur on this shore and with a maximum ice depth of four feet, it is possible that sheet ice in the break-up may be up-ended and gouge into the shallow water, with possible damage to the pipeline.

On the other hand, if the formation of the ground should be favourable at the well, it might be preferable to
connect an intake into the well and pump directly from the well into the proposed 4,000 gallon pressure tanks in the boiler room. Taken on the whole, I am inclined to recommend that the latter procedure be adopted, with an 8" pipe between the lake and the well, with double strainer on the lake end.

The pump house is proposed to house an eight or twelve horse-power gasoline engine, together with a suitable pump, and will be kept heated in the winter time with a stove. The water line from the pump house to the school will be below frost line, and should be fairly easily constructed for the most part.

A fire hydrant should be located some thirty feet away from the new building with a shut-off valve in the 4" main, so that in the event of a fire, the hydrant will function, either with the closed valve or pumping into hose as well as into the pressure tanks.

The dimensions of the boiler house are shown, in which it is proposed to house the pressure tanks, with a water pressure of forty pounds into the tank and coming out into the school service at around twenty-five or thirty pounds.

Owing to lack of space it is suggested that these tanks be placed on top of the other on an I steel frame and connected together, with a trip valve at the entry.

Regarding a site for a tank as outlined in the third last paragraph of your letter and instructions, the total water used will be around 10,000 to 15,000 gals. per diem, and with the use of two pressure tanks in the boiler room there would be around 4,000 gals. always on hand, and with the centrifugal pump, it would simply be a matter of pumping sometime in the morning and afternoon. There are no pressure tanks at the school. No existing water system is in the school, except the old summer service on the top of the ground, with a small gasoline engine on the lake shore.

Please instruct me as to any other further information which may be required, as careful note was made of all pertinent data, when visiting the school.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) W. G. Stuart.
April 15, 30

Sir,

Plans have now been prepared in connection with the water supply and fire protection system for the St. Bruno Indian Residential School. We have also prepared an estimate of cost for the construction of the works and for the necessary material, copies of which are attached.

The estimate of cost for the 40,000 gallon elevated tank was submitted by the Dominion Bridge Company and is considered a trifle high. We have therefore requested the Horton Steel Works of Toronto to submit an estimate for this work. With the amalgamation of the Riverside Iron Works and the Manitoba Iron Works with the Dominion Bridge Company, it is now impossible to get competitive bids on this class of work in western Canada.

Our estimate includes the figures submitted by the Dominion Bridge Company, as it was thought advisable to get the scheme under consideration by the Department of Indian Affairs with as little further delay as possible because it is not considered that an alternative bid will reduce the cost of the tower by more than a few hundred dollars. Mr. Towers is ready to take his men on to the job at a moment's notice to start work on the pipeline excavation and the concrete base for the tower and pumping plant.

The Dominion Bridge Company has advised us that if awarded the contract for the tower, they will manufacture same at their new plant in Calgary and will commence work on it within two or three weeks from date of order.

In regard to the material for the pipeline, Messrs. Bell and Morris have informed us that the pipes will be shipped from Toronto immediately upon receipt of order.

Would you please forward a copy of the plans and estimate to the Department of Indian Affairs and ascertain from them whether they wish to proceed with the works.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) J. S. Tempest,
Commissioner of Irrigation.

The Director,
Water Power & Reclamation,

Ottawa, June 6, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

I write to inform you, with regret, that the item in the Department's Estimates to complete the new building at the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School has been disallowed and that there are, therefore, no further funds for the payment of accounts this year. I have reviewed the expenditure in connection with the building, and I find that in the fiscal year 1929-30 the Department paid nearly $41,000. There has already been paid this fiscal year - since April first - $11,780 and there are unpaid accounts on the file, which will now be paid, amounting to $3,780.

I regret that the Department cannot favourably consider any further time sheets or accounts for materials. The shelving and cupboards and furnishing, the laundry equipment, the electric light and the water supply will have to stand until funds are provided by Parliament.

Dear Mr. Scott—

I hope you will not find me too persistent in coming to ask you to take a very special interest in the matter of securing the furniture for our new house. I was speaking about the opening of our school after vacation to His Lordship Bishop Guy, as we want to receive the pupils in their new quarters and their return to the Mission. He advised me to write to you immediately asking if you could possibly give your full approval which would enable us to make the purchase as soon as possible, and prepare it all during vacation. I might state here that His Lordship said you would probably come out to see him this summer; that would mean a visit to St. Bruno's. What an honor it would be for me all, to open wide the doors of our beautiful school for the first time, to its greatest and most generous benefactor. We are hoping that this trip will not be...
Sister Mary Gilberte,

I am writing to express our anticipation of his visit. We know that His Lordship, Bishop Amy, is an intimate friend of yours. His presence among us seems to make you more at ease. He has been here frequently and we love to receive him. He is so kind, so understanding and sympathetic.

If it were possible, we would wish to give him a princely reception at each visit, but just now this is almost impossible. The house and its apartments are not being equipped as yet. However, I know you will understand our present predicament and, as you have so often done before, come to our aid.

The letter sent recently by Mr. MacKenzie somewhat disheartened me at first; it seems so hard to have to put up with another few months of hardship caused by the lack of water and laundry equipment, hiring the laundress. I can speak through experience, but as in the other cases, this problem placed under your care and attention is sure to succeed.

Should my request be granted, kindly tell me which firm you would like to patronize.

Yours very sincerely,

Sister Mary Gilberte
Grouard, Alta., June 26th, 1930.

Dr Duncan C. Scott,

Dear Doctor Scott:

Rev. Father Giroux and Rev. Sister Mary Gilberte have referred to me their correspondence with regard to present difficulties re the completion and furnishing of St Bruno's Indian Residential School. Their intention is obviously that I take up the matter with you personally.

At the time the last letter from the Department was received, removal of the old furnaces had been done and excavation for the new power (or boiler) building started. The principal is at a loss how to proceed as the boilers and furnaces which are already on the ground must be installed before Winter. At this time of the year labor is cheap and the principal is more than anxious to see the work brought to completion.

I understand that lack of funds is responsible for orders lately received at St Bruno. May I suggest that the principal (or our Corporation) be allowed to borrow from the Bank such amount as will be necessary to complete the work or such amount that you may think fit, same to be reimbursed the principal (or the Corporation) when funds will be provided by Parliament.

Regarding the furnishings, a list of which has been supplied the Department by Rev. Sister Mary Gilberte, May I make the same suggestion?

The Department is to be congratulated on the work done at St Bruno and it would be almost a disaster if same was not brought to a proper completion. I understand that you intend coming to St Bruno this year. I would be more than pleased to meet you there and even bring you to St Bernard's School and Mission.

Hoping to be favored with the acceptance of the above suggestions and even begging the advantage of a telegram addressed at Grouard as the matter is pressing, I remain

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

You remember that Bishop Guy wrote concerning the completion of the work at the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School. He represented that the new boilers and other mechanical plant should be installed and that the furnishings should be secured this year and he suggested that the Church might borrow the money until the Department could arrange for an appropriation. You asked His Lordship for an estimate of the cost.

The following figures have now been received. You will note that practically all the work and equipment that is required to really complete the new wing is requested. However, there is no mention of electric light or water supply, which have been estimated at $2,400 and $27,400, respectively.

Labour since May 17th, including boiler house ...... $6,237.00

Installation of mechanical plant,
(including the supplying of laundry equipment and bake oven) ...... 6,800.00

Installation of water supply and arranging for laundry sewage disposal... 2,750.00

Furnishings ......................... 2,435.00

Miscellaneous ....................... 792.00

Total .................. $19,014.00

It is not clear whether the cupboards and shelving, etc., are included in these figures.

We have already paid approximately $17,500 from this year's Vote for this school. There is no item for the purpose in the Main Estimates and the one in the Supplementaries was disallowed. The only suggestion I can make is that Bishop Guy's proposal, to borrow the money, be approved.

Russell Perrier
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Bishop Guy:

I have Your Lordship's letter of the 9th ultimo, estimating the cost of completing the work at the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School. I note that you do not include the electric light or the water supply. I take it for granted that these improvements can stand until next year.

The item for this school was disallowed in our Supplementary Estimates and the accounts we have already paid this year have had to be charged to the general Appropriation for Indian Education. This Vote is really completely assigned and I regret that the Department is forced to accept Your Lordship's proposal. Arrangements should be made to have the really necessary work completed by church funds. Time sheets and receipts, in duplicate, should be kept, showing the expenditure. I shall arrange to have an item in next year's Appropriation to reimburse the church authorities.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

ST. BRUNO'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (R.C.) Cont'd.

experience at teaching in Indian schools. There are 45 boys and 63 girls enrolled.

The school building is an up-to-date, modern frame building, and, being practically new, is in splendid condition. The building is heated with hot water, and lighted with electric light. Water is on tap throughout the building.

The water supply is pumped from the lake. The installation is at present only a temporary one, but it has worked very satisfactorily during the present winter. It will be necessary to put the pipes down deeper below the frost line and carry them farther out into the lake in order to insure permanency.

The building provides two large, well equipped dormitories. In the boys' dormitory there are 50 beds, 24 basins, 3 baths, and 3 toilets. In the girls' dormitory there are 65 beds, 28 basins, 3 baths, and 3 toilets.

Fire protection consists of stand pipes with hose connections on each floor and a number of chemical fire extinguishers conveniently placed throughout the building. The building is three stories high with a basement. Three outside stairway fire escapes are provided with easy access to them on each floor. An outside stairway is placed at each end of the building, and one in the centre. I was informed that the children are being given instruction in fire drill. I found this building in excellent condition throughout.

An ample supply of wholesome food is provided. The children are given milk, as well as meat and
ST. BRUNO'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (R.C.) Cont'd.

and vegetables, daily. They have a well nourished appearance, and I heard no complaints regarding the food supplied at this school.

Seven cows are kept for milking purposes. They have a large garden, but last year the potato crop was a failure, and they have to purchase their supply. They had, however, plenty of carrots and other vegetables for their requirements.

They have a large laundry room, but the only equipment is five set tubs and some small old wash tubs and hand machines. The Sisters say that washing for 112 children makes heavy work for both the children and the staff, and they would like to be supplied with two medium sized washers, an extractor, mangle and section of drier, a low pressure boiler for heating hot water for the laundry, and a stove for heating the irons. They can do the bulk of their washing then with power and still have sufficient small clothes left to provide instruction for the girls.

The girls are given instruction in sewing, knitting, and fancy work, as well as in general housework. The boys assist with the garden work and care of the stock.

Wood has been exclusively used for fuel until this winter. A seam of coal was discovered about four miles from the school building, and 50 tons were secured at the beginning of the winter. This coal has proved to make very satisfactory fuel.

This is a very strongly constructed washer built for heavy duty. The material throughout is of the best grade and no pains have been spared to produce a machine that can be relied upon to give many years of satisfactory service.

The Main Trunion Journals operate in roller bearings. Less power is required to drive the machine and wear is almost entirely eliminated, with the result that all gears are always in correct mesh and alignment. Broken gears, worn trunion journals and bearing replacements are never necessary on this washer. The main bearings are entirely separated from the tub by packed stuffing boxes, which absolutely prevents oil and grease from entering the washer or water from coming out.

The Reversing Movement is our Beaver Ball Bearing type in which all the thrust of operating the belt shifter slides is taken by hardened steel balls. The movement is designed so as to give a positive even shifting of the belts, irrespective of wear, so that the cylinder...

runs the same number of revolutions in either direction. The gears are machine cut from solid blanks and the main gear is thirty inches in diameter. The gear has a split hub to facilitate easy removal. A combined gear lock and hand wheel is provided.

The Outer Case is of the finest clear Cypress and is furnished with a brass apron at the door opening. Inspection plates are provided in each end so that trunion bolts may be tightened without removing the upper half of the case.

Dear Mr Ferrier:

Upon my return I discussed with Rev. Fr Falher the water system question as suggested by you and Mr Scott during my visit in Ottawa.

We are both of opinion that the present temporary system installed by us could be made permanent by certain alterations and changes that would entail an expense that would range between $1500.00 and $2000.00. The water supply would then be assured satisfactorily for quite a number of years thus relieving the Department from the heavy expense expected.

However, the amount referred to above would not include the erection of a water tower or a water tank, the former outside or the latter inside. We have presently a pneumatic tank in the basement. If same could be changed to a larger one I presume we could easily substitute the new pressure tank to the water tower or inside water tank (which would work from the upper story).

My Dear Doctor Scott:

Regarding St Bruno everything is in order and labour returns, receipts and invoices in part are presently in Mr Ferrier's office. Pending the sending of the balance could you not send us a partial payment at least to allay the situation.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE THOMAS G. MURPHY.

In June, 1929, with the concurrence of the Honourable Charles Stewart, the Department arranged to enlarge the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School, near Grouard, Alta. In view of the location, the Church authorities were given the responsibility for the undertaking, on a day labour basis. Plans were prepared by the Department Architect and the work was proceeded with. The Department gave instructions that competitive prices were to be secured and that local labour was to be engaged as far as possible. During the fiscal year 1929-30, the expenditure for the new building amounted to $39,980.14. During the past fiscal year, $23,591.20 was expended. Last year, funds were not available to complete the work, but it was extremely desirable that the building activity should be continued. It was therefore arranged that the Oblate Order should pay the bills and then present receipts for reimbursement this year. You will remember that there is an item of $37,000 in the current Appropriation for this purpose and to complete the mechanical plant. Receipts, amounting to $18,544.52, are now to hand, and, with your concurrence, I propose to make reimbursement to His Lordship Bishop J. Guy, O. M. I., of Grouard.

I may say that all of the $37,000 available will not be expended. In addition to the present payment, there will be purchased this year laundry machinery at a cost of $2,275; there will be improvements to the water supply, at a cost of $1,750; and approximately $800 will be required to put the electric lighting plant in good condition. The electric plant is a used one, from another of our schools, where Hydro is available. I expect that the building will be completed at a total cost this year of less than $25,000, which, of course, includes the present payment. I have asked Mr. Ferrier, who is informed concerning the matter, to offer any explanation you require.

A. S. Williams,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Re: Installation of lighting for St. Bruno's School.

Dear Sir:

After making an inspection of the second-hand equipment and checking the wiring and load at this school, we believe it would be to your advantage to install complete new equipment somewhat larger than the present plant. Your power load alone consisting of motors already connected, require more power than the 7½ K.W. generator would deliver. On top of this you would also have your lighting load. Taking this into consideration we would recommend that you install not less than a 10 K.W. generator. We are making an estimate of a plant of this size, using a semi-Diesel type of engine which uses crude oil for fuel. The first cost of the plant would be a little greater, but the saving of fuel would more than off-set the greater cost.

We also found that the wiring in parts of your building and the line is in very bad shape. This creates a great fire hazard and we are also quoting you a separate estimate on the clearing up of this work.

The plant we are quoting you is in stock in Winnipeg, so immediate delivery could be made.

We are submitting a tentative estimate on repairing and installing your 7½ K.W. plant. If you decide to have the plant installed it would have to be shipped to Edmonton, where we would give you a detailed estimate on complete over-haul.

* MEMBER ALBERTA ELECTRICAL ASSOCIATION *
However no guarantee could be given as to the power delivery or life of the plant. In our estimation the plant is completely worn out and it would be folly on your part to install this plant, more especially since your school is in such an isolated position. Many parts of the plant are missing, there being no water tanks, switch board, piping, silencer, etc., and some parts of the engine are missing also.

Enclosed you will find estimate on plant and a rough sketch of the installation in the space reserved in the engine room for the plant.

Dear Sir:

Re: Your letter of October 6th, No.-131-4-5

In answer to your letter re, plant at the Blue Quill Indian School. In checking over this plant we find that there was no switch board, no fuel tank or cooling tank, no piping of any kind, also several small parts of the engine were missing. Also the generator commutator needs turning down and new brushes etc.

As we stated in our letter to the principal of the school we considered that the engine could not be repaired except at a cost equal to that of a new engine. The generator can be repaired at a very small cost but this generator is not large enough to handle the load now connected at this school. If the plant was repaired and installed you would find that it would be greatly over-loaded from the start and would have to be replaced in a short time.

The foundation, piping, tank, switch board etc., needed to install this plant, amounting to nearly one thousand dollars would be of no use when installing a larger plant at some future date. Therefore we would recommend that if possible a larger plant should be installed at this time, using a crude oil engine. The generator when repaired could be used in some smaller school with a new engine.

Our quotation on the work amounting to $2535.00, was $750.00 for the batteries, F.O.B. Indiana and $1785.00 for the supply of new parts, installing foundations etc. for the new plant, batteries and engine.

Dear Sir,

Re Payment for Addition to St. Bruno's Indian Residential School

Education cheque No. 2268 for $18,544.52 was issued on August 10th, last, in favour of the Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Grouard, Alberta, to reimburse them for expenditures made during 1930 in connection with the enlargement of St. Bruno's school. I desire to draw your attention to the following remarks in connection with this payment:

(1) An explanation of this payment is given on your form 52 accompanying the accounts, from which I infer that your department was liable for the expenditures but that, as funds were not available from the appropriation for 1930-31, the Corporation was requested to pay the accounts and to submit receipts for re-inbursement from this year's funds.

In this connection I would refer you to Section 49, Sub-Section 2, of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act which states that "all estimates submitted to Parliament shall be for the services coming in course of payment during the fiscal year," and to Section 60 which requires me to direct the attention of the House to all payments charged to the appropriation accounts which "did not occur within the period of the account". The intention of these sections, it appears to me, is to prevent such payments as the one in question.

The Deputy Supt. General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I am therefore of opinion that if authority could not have been obtained for the payment of this account in 1930-31, the amount should have been specifically mentioned in the estimates for 1931-32, in order that Parliament might know they were voting moneys for an indebtedness incurred in a previous year. As neither of these courses was followed, I am of opinion that the approval of the Governor in Council should have been obtained before payment was made.

(2) Included in the total payment are two items of $203.27 for material supplied by Gaults Alberta Limited. The vouchers are similar in all details except that one is marked "copy". Apparently a duplicate payment of $203.27 has been made. This firm's account of December 17th for $149.73 provided for a discount of three per cent. if paid within ten days of the first of the following month, but though payment was made on January 8th the discount was not deducted, resulting in an overpayment of $4.49.

(3) The accounts submitted by the J.H.Ashdown Hardware Company, which total $455.87, have not been receipted. They contain the following overpayments: accounts for $2.26, $2.15 and $.55 dated March 4th and 6th, 1930 were all previously paid by Education cheque No.1549 of June 9th, 1930; account for $4.34 dated March 18th, 1930 was included twice in account paid by cheque No. 1549; discount of two per cent. on statement of account of September 17th was not deducted, causing an overpayment of $3.05.

(4) Seventeen labour paylists for the period December 1st to March 28th have not been properly certified.

(5) In many cases freight charges by the various firms are not supported by way-bills or receipted vouchers. These should be supplied in all cases.

I desire to again draw your attention to Section 54 and Section 58, subsection 21 of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act which provides, respectively, that the

departmental
departmental officers shall audit the details of the several accounts in the first place, and that the vouchers bear evidence of having been completely checked. The vouchers covering the payment in question are being returned to you under separate cover in order that the matters referred to in this letter may be adjusted.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Gentlemen:

We are in receipt of your letter of January 28th in connection with the St. Bruno Indian Residential School -- MacKillop Electric Company. We note your different remarks regarding the discrepancies in these accounts. We immediately got in touch with the MacKillop Electric Company, and have had these accounts amended and are returning same herewith.

In connection with Invoice No. 628, we are enclosing a letter from the MacKillop Electric Company in which they explain this matter. Apparently, there was no specific contract, but was a verbal arrangement between the Rev. Father Falher and the MacKillop Electric Company. No doubt, it was installed in order to cover the necessary inspection for a school of this type in order to give the proper fire alarm to prevent any trouble in any part of the school. We understand the previous arrangement was not according to regulations.

With reference to Invoice No. 631, this was a clerical error, the correct amount being $129.51. This has been amended, no figures other than the total being changed. On Invoice No. 634, the labor was put in at $17.50 instead of $17.00 and this was also a clerical error. The amount, however, of the bill is $37.50.

We trust that the above explanation will now put these in order and that they will be passed and a remittance forwarded as soon as convenient.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that I am in receipt of a letter from the Reverent Principal of the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School at Joussard, Alberta, asking for permission to sell an old lighting plant which he has at the school.

From information I have received, some years ago the Department shipped the St. Bruno School a lighting plant from some other school, possibly Gleichen. Later on when the new school was built at St. Bruno's, a new lighting plant was put in as the other one was old and practically worn out and much too small for the new building. The Reverent Principal now informs me that he has an opportunity of selling this old plant although he has not stated the price obtainable.

I have informed him that I am not in a position to grant this authority, but am submitting the matter to the Department. If it is order for him to sell this old plant, I would ask that his request be granted, as the plant in question is useless there, and will only deteriorate from year to year.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, stating, in detail, the equipment comprised in the old lighting plant on hand at the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School. It is noted that this plant was transferred from the Peigan R.C. Residential School to the St. Bruno's School during the year 1924.

We are not aware as to what value should be placed on this plant, which you state consists of a 20 H.P. engine, dynamo, 4 H.P. motor, switchboard and batteries. If the Principal is unable to dispose of the entire plant at a fair price, I would request that he arrange to have same stored until the Department is able to make arrangements to have it transferred elsewhere.

In the event of this plant being sold, the proceeds should be forwarded to the Department for credit of the Receiver-General. However, before completing the sale and delivery of the equipment, you should inform the Department definitely as to the amount that would be received and if you consider same a fair remuneration.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have to bring to your attention a rather serious situation which has just been declared at St Bruno Indian Residential School.

The school is of rather recent construction, I mean the new portion of the building, and we have found that the beams and first floor are all rotten on account of the presence of water. The house is threatening to collapse and in different places, specially where there are columns, the floor gives in.

I would ask you to send as soon as possible, as the matter is pressing, a building inspector, to report and advise for immediate action.

Yours very truly,

Bishop of Grouard.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 131-45 of March 21st, in connection with St. Bruno's Indian Residential School at Grouard, in which you state that His Lordship Bishop Guy of Grouard had reported that the first floors were all rotten, threatening the collapse of the building.

I have just returned from the Peace River country where I spent a week and while there I spent a couple of days at St. Bruno's School, and investigated the trouble thoroughly.

This building was only erected something like 4 years ago and is an addition to the old school. The heating plant, machinery, &c., are all located in the basement of the older part of the building, and the rooms in the basement of the new part are the kitchen, pantry and the girls' and boys' dining rooms. The basement floor is practically at ground level. The foundation under the building is of surface cement. The floor consists of stringers, 12 X 12, placed on the ground, and 2 X 12 floor joists placed on top of the stringers, then a rough floor, paper and edge-grained fir flooring.

On investigation I found that the floor in the boys' dining room is all rotten; also in the hall next to the dining room and part of the kitchen. The reason for this is that the school is

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6368, file 762-5, part 3))
built on ground which slopes towards the lake. Evidently the water has been getting under the foundation and I found that underneath the floor there was nothing but muck. As there was no air passage under the floor, no doubt the ground has been wet there all the year round, which has caused the rotting of the floor. One part of the floor in the dining room, an area of about 6 X 12', had dropped down onto the ground and the joists under the floor in the dining room and part of the kitchen are simply rotten; The wood can be pulled away with your hands, and it would not be long before the whole of the dining room floor would cave in. If this happened it would be disastrous to the rest of the building, as the partitions that are holding the upper floor in place would, of course, gradually sink with the floor, causing destruction to the upper floors and roof.

To repair this damage, I have the following suggestions to make: That the flooring and joists be taken out of the above-mentioned rooms to be replaced by a layer of gravel and stone, and filled in with cement. The joists should be sunk into the cement and then a wooden floor placed on top of the joists. This would prevent anything of this nature happening again. The present flooring could be used as first flooring as the latter is all rotten, as well as the joists, and we would only have to purchase a new top flooring. The sand, gravel and stone can be procured on the lake shore, which is only a few hundred yards from the school. We can employ Indian labour and teams to haul this to the school. I am attaching hereto a list of the material required. This will have to be purchased in Edmonton and I can arrange for this. The Department will realize that while the work is being proceeded with it might transpire that something else is required which would necessitate the purchasing of additional material. It might be well to put weeping tile drain around the school to keep the water from getting under the remainder of the foundation that is apparently intact.
It was very difficult to get at the trouble as the floor is only about 18 inches from the ground, and we had to take up the flooring in several places. I engaged the services of a carpenter from High Prairie, Mr. Reykdal, who had done considerable work for us. I would also recommend that he be engaged to do the work. He does not wish to take out a contract as he does not know exactly what it is going to run up to, so we would pay him the minimum wage for carpenter foremen. All he requires is another carpenter and the rest of the work can all be done by Indians. The wages we should pay the Indians would be $2.50 per day for team, man and wagon, and about $1.50 per day for a single man.

I discussed the matter thoroughly with the Principal, Rev. Father Falher, and he was of the same opinion as I am, that the above method of repairing the school is the only feasible one. However, if our Architect has something better to suggest, we would be pleased to follow any suggestions that would be more suitable than the above-stated plan. The Department will readily understand that we may run into something else when we get the floor out, although I do not think this will happen, as the carpenter got under part of the floor in the girls' dining room which adjoins the boys' dining room.

I am attaching hereto a floor plan of the school which will assist the Department in understanding what I am writing about. It will be necessary for us to rent some jacks to jack up the partitions, as in one or two places I found that they had given away to a small degree. The school owns a cement mixer.

I hope I have made myself quite clear and that the Department will understand that immediate steps should be taken to have this attended to. If the work is carried on as I have suggested, the Agent would have to be
furnished with an accountable cheque so as to enable him to pay the workers every Saturday night.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Memorandum

Doctor McGill,

With reference to Inspector Christianson's letter hereunder, regarding the condition of the basement floor at the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School it would appear that there is grave danger of the interior of the building collapsing unless something is done immediately. I do not agree with Inspector Christianson that a new wood floor be installed over the top of the concrete, but would recommend that a concrete floor be provided in the basement. It would be a waste of labour and material to place a wood floor on the top of the concrete.

Without seeing the building it is rather difficult to make an accurate estimate of the cost, but I would recommend that an expenditure not exceeding $500.00 be authorized, and that as much of the labour as possible be performed by the school. I have been advised by the Schools Branch that $500.00 is available.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th addressed to the Deputy Superintendent General, with reference to the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School and in reply to say that $500.00 is available for providing a new floor in the basement of the School.

I note your recommendation with reference to the means of providing this new floor, but I think it would be more practical to install a new concrete floor in the basement. It is not necessary to place wood joists and wood floor on top of the concrete. The life of a floor laid in this manner is very short. A straight concrete floor with the proper feetings for the partitions would be much more serviceable.

It is expected that the school will supply some of the labour and in this manner keep the cost within the above mentioned amount. If the services of a foreman are required Mr. Reyhial of High Prairie may be employed.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to refer you to my letter No. 405-11A.R.O. of the 7th instant, in connection with the St. Bruno School. In going over the damage done at this school by the water getting under the foundation and rotting the joists, the Agent and myself were of the opinion at first that there must be a spring on the slope back of the school, but as Father Falher, the Principal, had been there for years and also a great many of the Sisters, they assured us that they had never heard of a spring being there, and I came to the conclusion we were wrong, and the water that was getting under the building was simply from rain, snow, &c.

I am now in receipt of a letter from Mr. L'Heureux, the Agent, stating that last Sunday he met Mr. G. Dandurant, who was the head carpenter when this school was erected, and he informed him that when the school was being built he found a small spring at the southeast corner of the building, and at the time he wanted Father Giroux, then Principal, to have the spring drained to a depth and pour concrete where the water would come in contact with the foundation, but Father Giroux did not want to use concrete for the sake of economy, and construction was made regardless of the spring. You will note by the plan that the boys' dining room, where most of the trouble is, is located in the southeast portion of the building.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
so it is quite plain now that this spring was covered up at the time of the construction and the water from it has worked its way under the foundation and kept the earth under the building continually wet, which has caused the rotting of the joists, floor, &c. Therefore, when the repair is made it will be necessary to clean out this spring and give it an outlet to some other point.

I mentioned in my report that Mr. Reykdal, who is one the preferred list, would act as foreman, but that he needed the services of another carpenter. Mr. Dandurand is anxious to get work, and I would like to know if it would be in order to take him on when this work is gone on with. I understand he is a first class carpenter, and evidently he is as he was the foreman when the building was erected. He lives at Donnelly, Alta., a town West of High Prairie.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 131-45 of the 15th instant in connection with the floor in St. Bruno Indian Residential School, and note that $500 is available for providing this. I also note what you have to say about wood joists and floor on top of the concrete. I suggested the straight concrete floor to the school authorities, but the sisters objected strenuously to the concrete and it was so accede to their wishes that I recommended the wooden floor. The delay in answering your letter was caused by the fact that I was away at Saddle Lake Agency and just returned yesterday morning.

I note in the last paragraph of your letter you state that if the services of a foreman are required, Mr. Reykdal of High Prairie may be employed; I take it from this that you question whether or not a foreman is required. In using the word "foreman" it was not intended that we were going to employ Mr. Reykdal to stand around and supervise the work. Someone reliable must be in charge, as the whole building could easily be affected when tearing up the flooring, &c., by letting one of the partitions drop, and Mr. Reykdal would be working as well as the others, but would have charge of the men employed.

I am taking steps to have this work gone on with along the line suggested in your letter.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to refer the Department to my letters of May 7th. and 14th., 405-11A.R.C. in connection with the damage done to the Foundation and floors in the St. Bruno Indian Residential School, in the Lesser Slave agency.

The Department authorized $500.00 for this work to be carried on, and to hire Mr. Reykdal as working foreman in connection with the work.

The Department also intimated that a concrete floor would be more suitable and last longer, if a joice and a wooden floor was placed on top of the concrete. I gave this information to the agent and told him to take this up with the principal as I knew the principal was anxious to put a board floor on top of the concrete, and as I have had no reply from them I was of the opinion that the school authorities were satisfied with the instructions of the Department as to the concrete floor.

During the time I was away on my holidays a letter came in from the agent stating that the school principal wanted to put the board floor on top of the concrete, also that he wanted to dispense with the services of Mr. Reykdal, as he was getting .65¢ per hour whereas he could hire a competent carpenter for .30¢. I could not comply with this as it was contrary to the wishes of the Department, and the man was not on the approved list. I therefore wired to the agent not to go on with the work any further until the Deputy Minister and I arrived there.

While up there with Dr. McGill I looked into the matter and found that the work of putting down the floor in the boys' dining room was not completed, and required either the board floor on top or another layer of concrete, and as only $41.59 was left out of the appropriation of $500.00 I could not authorize the work to be gone on with. The principal evidently is quite determined that he wants a board floor on top of the concrete, Mr. Reykdal advised me that it would take approximately $150.00 to complete the work. If the Department do not feel like putting up any more money I suppose it will be in order to inform the school that they could complete the balance of the work whenever they wish to but that the Department would only be responsible for the balance of the appropriation which is expended.

I realize, however, that putting the board floor on top of the concrete will not be very satisfactory. The money expended to date has been well spent, as it took a lot of gravel and sand to fill up the hole caused by taking out the flooring and parts have been placed on cement foundations etc. to keep the upstairs floor from sagging, but an important point is getting rid of the water from the spring which is under the southeast corner of the building. Putting in the cement floor gets rid of the water from the spring on that side of the building but I understand now that it has worked its way to the other end and in time will ruin the whole foundation of the building.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your 405-11A. R.C. of the first instant, in connection with the drain under the foundation and also with reference to the flooring of the boys' dining room, at the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School.

Regarding the drain under the foundation, you may arrange for the purchase and forwarding to the school of the quantity of three inch piping and the cement required and also for the labour in installing the drain. It is noted you recommend that this drain be put right under the school, to carry off water from a spring under the foundations. Mr. S. J. Reykdahl may be engaged to perform the labour. The total cost for material and labour should be kept within your estimate of $295.00, if possible.

With reference to the completion of the floor in the boys' dining room, the Department is not prepared to authorize the installation of a board floor on top of the cement. It is considered that, if a smooth cement finish was placed over the concrete floor which has been recently put down, this would be satisfactory, and the floor could then be covered with Battleship linoleum. The Department has authorized an expenditure of $500.00 for installing the cement floor - $300.00 of this amount being forwarded to Mr. Agent L'Heureux to pay for labour. This is the full amount that it is possible to provide towards the cost of the flooring; and, if this amount is exceeded in completing the floor, the school authorities will have to be responsible for payment of any expense over that amount. Should you consider it necessary, you may arrange for the purchasing and forwarding of the quantity of linoleum that would be required for this floor - obtaining a good, serviceable grade.

After the work in connection with the drain and the flooring is completed, I would request that you forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering all costs. As stated above, $500 is all the Department can provide towards the cost of the cement floor. You should have Mr. Agent L'Heureux forward you time sheets, properly certified, in accounting for the expenditure of the advance of $300, which was sent him - these to be sent to the Department by you.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, No. 131-4-5 in connection with repairs to the floor under the new wing of St. Bruno's Indian Residential School: As the Department are aware I reported on this in my letter No. 405-11A.R.C. of May 7th, last, when I pointed out that the whole of the floor in the dining-room and part of the kitchen and hall had to be replaced. The sum of $500.00 was authorized to repair the floor and before the floor in the dining-room was completed the appropriation was exhausted. The dining-room floor is just rough cement with no finishing top on it. I was authorized to purchase linoleum to cover the floor but there is no use doing this as long as the floor is unfinished as at the present time, and there are no funds available for this work, and the school authorities do not seem to be inclined to do it.

I was just writing the Agent in this connection when I received your letter. The floor that is mentioned in the Agent's letter is what was reported on in my letter above referred to. I now have the following suggestion to make:

Mr. Reykdahl has been doing the work for us up in that part of the country as the Department are aware. He is a very good carpenter, but probably lacks experience in handling a matter of this kind. In my opinion the matter of this floor gradually rotting under the building is serious. The drain we put under the floor will probably in time dry up the earth, but this will take some time, and if it is successful it will prevent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
further rotting. I think we should have someone with more experience than Mr. Reykdahl to look after the repairing of the floors there, as unless it is attended to properly it will probably ruin the building altogether. As the Department are aware, this was an addition built onto the old school building. I would suggest that the matter be left in abeyance until the frost goes out of the ground next spring, and that Mr. Gardner-Smith be sent up there to look after the repairs. He has had a great deal of experience with the building of our schools and to put the floors of this building into first class shape again so that there is no danger of the foundation caving in will be quite expensive. The only time to do this would be during the summer holidays as the floor would all have to be torn up in the kitchen, hall, &c. Hiring men who are really not competent to do work of this nature is more or less of an experiment, whereas if the work was placed in Mr. E. Gardner-Smith's hands we would be assured of something permanent. I shall be glad to know what the Department think of my suggestion.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.
Ottawa, February 5, 1935.

Sir:

I have your 405-11A R.C. of the 15th ultimo, in connection with repairs to the floor under the new wing of the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School and also with reference to proper drainage. It is noted that the sum authorized for the repairs to the floor last summer was used up before the work was completed.

The Department will give consideration to your suggestion, that Mr. Gardner-Smith be sent up to the school next spring, to look after the work required in placing the floor in good condition and installing proper drainage to prevent the foundation of the building caving in. The cost involved will determine the work that can be carried out, as, owing to the expenditure this year, only a small amount was provided in our Appropriation for the coming year towards repairs at this school.

I would request that you draw this matter to the attention of the Department next spring.

Your obedient servant,
