Report on St. Bruno's Indian School.

Sir:

In accordance with instructions from the Department, I made a trip of inspection to the above school, where I spent two days. All arrangements for my transportation, and for my being met at the station, had been kindly made in advance by Mr. Inspector Christianson. I deemed it advisable to have the man come who did some work on the building last year, and he arrived the next day. This man, Mr. Reykdale, explained what he had done, and his reasons for doing it; and I learned from him all he knew about the situation. The Reverend Principal, Father Fallare, extended every courtesy and assistance.

The whole trouble is in the newer extension, built about six years ago. On entering its basement an unpleasant odour is very noticeable, coming from trapped water and rotting wood. I made small openings in the basement floor in several places, and with a flash-light I was able to examine the conditions below. I found 7" of water under part of this floor, and muddy soil under another part. Not wishing to cut the floors more than necessary, I bored 3/4" holes in other places, and made soundings with an iron rod. The soil conditions vary from several inches of water to only dampness. I was astonished at the extent of the rotting of the wood in so comparatively short a time, which perhaps can be explained by the entire lack of ventilation under the wood floors.

In an attempt to cope with the water under the floors, Mr. Reykdale had laid a tile drain, carrying it to a ravine about 150' behind the building. The outlet of this drain was not visible, having been carried to a covered place on the side of the ravine. I hired a labourer to dig out the end of the tile drain, and on exposing it, there was not a drop of water being carried. Later I found the other end of the drain at its starting place under the basement, and it was above the present water level, and doing no good.

I was told that last year the floor in the boys' refectory was breaking through from rottenness, and that Mr. Reykdale and helpers had removed the wood floor in this room and had replaced it with a deep concrete sub-floor, with nailing strips bedded in to take a finish lumber floor, but that the appropriation became exhausted, and the rough concrete sub-floor was as far as this work went, and little or no work was done under the rest of this basement, except to lay another little patch of flooring over weak spots which threatened to break through in various places.
In examining the conditions under the basement floor I was surprised to observe that instead of concrete being used, the construction is as follows: A laminated sill, about 12"x 12" is laid on the ground, and this mud-sill carries 2"x 12" joists, over which the shiplap sub-floor and finish fir floor are laid. This mud-sill is generally in contact with the soil, and on this account, and perhaps hastened by lack of ventilation, has become more or less rotten, varying in this respect in different places, and this rotting has spread to the joists and flooring. I enclose a small sample of wood taken from this mud-sill, which is fairly representative of the condition of this important member.

Feeling disinclined to believe that the Department's Architect had specified that the basement floor be laid in this way, I asked if a set of plans were available, and after a little search the blue prints of the addition were given me, which revealed the cause of all the trouble. On Plan #609, Sheet 1, Section at A.A. it shows clearly that the basement floor of the new extension was to consist of 6" of concrete, instead of which no concrete has been used, and lumber was substituted, as above described. In pointing this out to the Rev. Principal, he said it was the first he knew of this departure from the plans. He said that under the original building a concrete sub-floor was laid, over which was placed fir flooring, and that there has been no trouble of any kind in the basement.

In addition to the rotting of the basement floors as described, there is still a more serious feature. The interior supporting columns, of which there are eight, go right down to, and are resting on, these rotting mud-sills; and the carrying partitions also depend on the wood below for their support. As these supports disintegrate, the entire structure will be endangered, as you will readily understand. Already there is some settlement, but not very much as yet, but very suggestive of what would eventually develop if allowed to continue.

I was told that in excavating for the extension, some mistake was made, and the excavation was carried down two or three feet too far, and had to be re-filled. As the sub-soil moisture apparently is not very far down, it is possible that water was thus tapped, which may account for the water at present in evidence under this basement. Also, there is no provision for intercepting ground water around the footings by means of tile weeping drains. There are no downspouts from the eavestroughing of the newer building, and these troughs are joined to the troughing of the original building, and I'm sure there must often be overflowing of gutters in the extension.

The Rev. Principal states that the drains carrying the waste water and sewage from the new addition do not function well, and suggests that they be run separate from the original sewer, and be provided with a separate septic tank and disposal field. Not having had an opportunity of checking the fall of the lines in question I am not prepared to say whether or not this suggested change is necessary.
The superstructure of the building seems all in good condition, and I could see no fault with the workmanship. A few doors are sticking, and sagging a little, caused from settlement of the building, but such minor troubles as sticking doors are easily rectified when the cause is removed.

From the foregoing descriptions I think you will be able to form a fairly accurate mental picture of the conditions affecting the newer building. Everything seemed all right in the original structure.

To overcome the troubles I am convinced there is no other way but to remove all the existing flooring in the addition, including the joists and mud-sills. Temporary supports will have to be used to carry the beams above the basement floors, and under the carrying partitions of basement while the changes are being made. Concrete piers will have to be placed to carry the columns, and a footing and dwarf concrete wall to carry the bearing partitions. The water underlying the basement can be drained away by properly laid tile drains, which would not be difficult to do when the floors are out of the way. Then there should be a gravel fill, well tamped, brought up to within 6" of the finish floor level. The last 6" should be of good concrete, using an approved concrete hardener for the topping coat. By the means thus briefly outlined the trouble now threatening the building will be overcome, and the structure will then rest on the kind of foundation intended by the Architect.

Subsidiary to the remedial measures suggested, there would be some making good of woodwork on the floor angles; the providing of base throughout the basement; substituting new columns where too much rot has developed; placing two additional downpipes from gutters; placing a tile weeping drain around the footings of west and south walls of new addition to intercept ground water from higher ground behind; possibly some correction of drains as mentioned by the Rev. Principal; the jacking-up of beams and carrying partitions where necessary to restore levels; and minor corrections where found necessary as the work proceeds.

As to cost, it is difficult to give even an approximate estimate, but I would respectfully suggest that, if possible, the sum of $3000.00 be allocated for this work of restoration, and if it can be completed for less, then the balance could be returned. The Sister Superior thinks that it would best suit the operation of the school if the work could start about July 1st, when the children will be away. If a fair-sized crew were put to work I think it could be completed in one month.

All the foregoing is respectfully submitted.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Memorandum: Doctor McGill.

Right Reverend Bishop Guy has reported to the Department that the foundations of the St. Bruno Indian Residential School were in such condition that the building was in danger.

Mr. E. Gardner Smith was requested to make an inspection of this building, and report. He has made the inspection and has submitted a very detailed report on the existing conditions.

The whole trouble is in the new extension which was built about six years ago. In erecting this extension the Church authorities substituted wood sills and joists in place of concrete as shown on the plans prepared for the building. These sills being in contact with the soil and through lack of ventilation have become rotten. The rotting has spread to the joists and flooring and a considerable amount of water is lying in the ground under the floor. The most serious feature is the interior supporting columns, of which there are eight, resting on these rotten wood sills, also the carrying partitions. As these sills are disintegrating the entire structure is in danger, and in a very short time the centre of the building will collapse or sag.

There was also a serious error made when this extension was built when the excavation was carried down two or three feet further than was necessary, and had to be refilled. The foundation is therefore not resting on solid ground. An effort was made last year by the Staff to drain the water from underneath the floor, but the drain was not properly laid and was of no effect.

It is rather difficult to make an estimate of the cost of repair work of this nature, but it is considered that it should not exceed $5,000.00.

In a letter received from Mr. Christianson he points out the necessity of immediate action, and recommends that the matter be placed in the hands of Mr. Gardner Smith, as there is no one in that part of
the country who is capable of undertaking work of this kind and seeing that it is properly done.

It will be necessary to remove the entire basement floor of the building, replacing same with concrete on a solid foundation. This is the only way to preserve the building, and I would recommend that Mr. Gardner Smith be authorized to supervise this very important work.

Dear Doctor McGill:

Subsequent to my visit at your office Saturday last, I take the liberty of suggesting that amount required for repairs at St Bruno School be included in Supplementary Estimates if not too late for same and if too late, taken from sources different from amounts voted in favor of schools under my jurisdiction. I am positive, the Department in its foresight, takes care of emergency cases such as the one I refer to and I hope that you will act accordingly.

You are aware of my financial difficulties due largely to the fact that we borrowed money at intervals for the construction, upkeep and repairs of buildings in connection with Indian educational and hospitalization work. For the last few years specially the Department has not been over prodigal in its grants in my district. Of course I except this year when you have given consideration to my requests, a fact for which I have already expressed my gratefulness. I would certainly feel sad if this year's generous treatment were allayed by a reduction along the lines that you mentioned in our last interview.

I leave the matter to your kind and generous consideration and wish to thank you in anticipation.

Very truly yours,

Dear Bishop Guy,

I am in receipt of Your Lordship's letter of June 11th, with reference to the expenditure for repairs at the St. Bruno school.

I feel inclined to reproach myself as I fear that I may have unintentionally given you a gloomy prognosis regarding the expenditures at this point. I may assure Your Lordship that it is our intention to charge this item to our up population for unforeseen expenditure. However, the sum may run into a considerable figure and the up population referred to may not be sufficient to take care of the whole amount. In the meantime the items for other schools in your diocese will stand and I sincerely hope that it will not be necessary to reduce them for the purpose of meeting the unforeseen expenditure at St. Bruno school.

Sir:

After a somewhat adventurous journey over submerged railway track where it skirts the edge of Lesser Slave Lake, I arrived here about the middle of July.

My expected source of sand and gravel was covered by some 8 ft. of water, and quite inaccessible, the lake being reported to be 10 or 12 ft. above normal level. Several swollen rivers had poured their flood waters into this lake, and its only outlet became choked with debris and silt, and the level of the lake is not yet falling appreciably. After considerable prospecting I located a small bed of gravel just above the water level of the lake, but distant nearly 3 miles, and over a bush trail which we first had to occupy two places before loads could be hauled over the sod places. Just as the hauling of the gravel was well started it was stopped by a half-breed named Cunningham who claimed the gravel was on his land. I took the half-breed in Cree for half an hour, and after he had talked to the half-breed in Cree for half an hour, it was agreed that the hauling could continue on the condition that we employ the owner's two sons and two teams for the hauling. Not being able to find any other gravel I had to accept the ultimatum, or see our job tied up. Sufficient gravel is now on the job.

Our car of cement came through in the interval between wash-outs on the line. The mud-sills, joists and flooring in the basement have all been removed, and some of this lumber was so rotten that it fell to pieces in the handling. The water underlying the basement is now drained away, and I do not anticipate any more trouble in this regard. To-day we should finish the footings under the carrying partitions, and the dwarf concrete wall; also the reinforced footings under two columns. These will have to remain for perhaps a week before we can safely take down the temporary supports now sustaining the weight of the superstructure. In the meantime we have a deep fill to make, after which we can start on the concrete floors.

My little crew consists of three white men—Scott, Rykedale, and the latter's son, and about eight local Indians.

The school Sisters have had a temporary summer-kitchen built for them at the rear of the school, into which essential articles were moved, for during our work everything had to be moved out of the basement of the affected building, including the range, sink, etc.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

E. Gardner Smith
Inspector of Construction.

Report on Repairs to St. Bruno Indian School.

Sir:

The work of restoring the affected part of the above school is now well advanced, and should be entirely completed by the first week in September.

All the floors in the affected basement have been removed, including the joists and mud-sills. These joists consisted of 2"x 10", spaced at 24" centres, without bridging. A few 2"x 12" were mixed with the others, but had been notched down to the same level, which, of course, weakened them accordingly. Most of the joists had become rotten, also the mud-sills in most places, while other parts were still sound.

With the floors out of the way we were able to deal with the stagnant water underlying this basement, and with less trouble than I expected, we were successful in draining away all this foul-smelling water.

Four lines of studding were necessary to hold up the superstructure during the repair work, also posts to carry the beams. The bottoms of the carrying partitions were generally so rotten that we had to cut off the lower 3 feet, putting in fresh plates and new studs, and new joint. Beneath the carrying partitions we put concrete footings 2"x 10", and on these footings we ran dwarf concrete walls 7" thick, to meet the under plates of these partitions. We also jacked up these partitions where necessary to restore levels, about 2½" being the maximum settlement to correct.

Under the supporting columns we placed concrete piers, 36"x 36"x 18", each reinforced with 10 steel bars.

Next came the filling of the space previously occupied by the joists and sills. This took 100 loads of coarse heavy sand, and I kept three Indians busy with tampers while this material was being spread. It will make excellent insulation between the damp undersoil and the concrete floor.

We are now laying the concrete floors 6" deep, including 1½" topping coat treated with Master Mix Concrete Hardener, which will not only give a dust-proof surface, but is a waterproofing as well. These floors should be finished in two more days. The school staff have a strange antipathy to concrete floors, and wanted me to lay nailing strips in the concrete, with wood floors. I refused to consider this, and told them I thought they should have had lesson enough already with wood floors in a basement! The Sister Superior pointed out that in the kitchen especially the hard concrete would be very trying on the feet of those working there, and asked if they might have lino on this floor, and a narrow strip of lino along the adjoining corridor. I replied that I thought I might anticipate the Department's consent to this request provided...
it would not run us over the original estimate for the entire work of restoration. As it now seems certain that we shall not exceed the estimate, I have ordered AA battleship for the kitchen floor and 3" strip for the basement corridor. This material will be laid on a carpet-felt base, and both materials will be cemented down. The school people are cooperating in every possible way, and are lending us their concrete mixer, supplying oil, gas, etc., so perhaps the providing them with the lino is a sort of quid pro quo in return for what they are doing.

We have yet to dig a trench around two sides of the newer building, and to lay a tile weeping drain along the corresponding footings to intercept ground water from the higher ground behind. While the concrete wall is exposed we shall give it a heavy coating of hot asphalt pitch, and shall use gravel for back-filling this trench to within a foot or two of grade. This should insure against any further encroachment of ground water into this basement. The soil here generally inclines to dampness, and water lies but a short distance from the surface.

We have also to place another downpipe from the eavestrough of the newer building, which we shall connect with the tile weeping drain.

Inside the building we are installing new base, as most of the old base was too rotten to use again. Then there will be a few days' painting and varnishing, and the restoring of the kitchen and pantry fixtures which we had to cut off and move out of our way.

As already stated, the work should be entirely finished by the first week in September, and the building will then be in excellent condition in every way.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.
JOUSSARD, ALTA., AUG 26 27 1935

R. GUERNEY,

O.R.R., ARCHITECT, DEPT., INDIAN AFFAIRS, OTTAWA, ONT.

Dear Mr. Orr:

You will have received my night letter sent yesterday calling attention to the inadequacy of the kitchen flue in the new building. I am told that trouble has been experienced with this chimney because of insufficient draft, and as a larger new three-oven range is about to be installed, with a 9" pipe, I feel sure that the existing 6" x 8" flue will prove insufficient. I hesitated before sending you the message, but realizing that I was sent here to rectify the defective features of the newer building, I deemed it incumbent on me to inform you regarding this chimney, especially as it appears to me none too safe from a fire hazard viewpoint, and then to be guided by your instructions.

As mentioned in my telegram, the walls of the chimney are of single brick, and as it passes through woodwork, it is contrary to safe practice. Also, it is another instance of the disregard of the construction clearly shown on the blueprint, where the flue scales 12"x 12", with an 8" wall. On hearing from you, we shall either leave the chimney alone and hope for the best, or take it down and rebuild it according to the blue print, just as you instruct.

Perhaps I should also mention in this connection that both the bakery and laundry chimneys are of similar construction to that of the kitchen, although again the blue print called for 12"x 12" flues and an 8" walls. However, as I have heard no complaint regarding the draft of these chimneys I am not proposing to take them down, but thought of removing sufficient of the enclosing J-joint so I can inspect them for safety, and if they appear to need it, they could be cement-plastered over the brickwork as an extra precaution against fire eating through the single joints of their 4" walls. The main heating chimney appears to have been properly constructed, and of ample dimensions.

On the plan of the new addition it is written that the footings of the extension were to be carried down to the same level as those of the existing building. This requirement was disregarded, and the footings were stepped up 18", and are poor footings at that, consisting largely of cobbles stones, with a minimum of cement mixed with them. I believe it is largely if not entirely from this departure from the plans which allowed ground water to pass under the floors of the addition.

In digging the trench around the outside walls of the new addition we encountered considerable water seeping out of the ground, which is now being drained away by our newly placed weeping drain, over which we have put a heavy covering of gravel, so I feel sure the basement will remain dry in the future.

The main departure from the plans was in the substituting of wood instead of concrete for the basement floors. I could mention other minor faults in construction, but they are relatively unimportant. The conclusion, however, is inescapable...
that had the contractor carried out the construction in accordance with the plans supplied by the Architect, the $3000.00 expenditure now being undertaken would have been entirely avoided, and there would not be the present fire hazard from faulty chimneys. I feel it my duty to bring these matters sharply to your attention so that in the future you may take whatever steps you deem necessary to insure that important constructional requirements will not be disregarded.

Before receiving this letter Bishop Guy will have called on you, and will have mentioned the proposal to extend the kitchen 20' longer. I supplied him with rough sketches of the proposed extension, and an estimate of its cost.

The work in hand should be completed by the end of the first week in September, and unless detained for the rebuilding of the kitchen chimney, or the extending of the kitchen, or both, I expect to return to Calgary at the time mentioned.

With kind personal regards,

Your obedient servant,

E.Gardner-Smith,
Inspector of Construction.

Sir:

As previously advised, the work of restoration of the defective basement of the above school was completed during the first week in Sep't.

Acting on the Department's instructions, we took down the kitchen chimney and rebuilt it with the 12"x 12" flue called for in the drawings in place of the 8"x 8" that had been built. I'm quite certain that had we not done this there would have been insufficient draft for the larger new range recently procured, with its 12" smoke outlet, especially as trouble in this respect had already been experienced with the smaller range with a 7" outlet. Now the new chimney affords excellent draft, and the kitchen Sister is very happy over the change. No local bricklayer being procurable, I had to bring one from Edmonton, and pay his travelling expenses, but he gave excellent service. In order to avoid making the chimney excessively bulky passing through the rooms above, we constructed it in single brick, lined with 12" x 12" vitrified flue lining, which as you know, meets the requirements of safe construction. We used cement mortar tempered with about 10% lime.

Regarding the bakery chimney, as the part above the roof was disintegrating badly from the action of the weather on the lime mortar, we took it down to the level of the roof, and rebuilt it in cement mortar. While we had it down we were able to view the inside of the flue, by the aid of a flash-light and mirror, and, apart from being smaller than called for, and of single brick construction, there seemed no visible fire hazard. I also examined the brickwork of this chimney at a lower level, and decided against taking the whole chimney down, as the joints seemed all well filled and reasonably safe. The School Superior states that this chimney too gives insufficient draft, and smokes badly when the bake-oven is first lighted. I noticed,
that the bake-oven is situated some distance, with a long run of horizontal piping, and I suggested that they move the oven close to the chimney for better draft, which they are going to do.

With reference to the cost of the restoration work, I stated in my Report of May 19th that it might run to $3000.00, but that if it could be done for less, then the balance could be returned. Including the chimney costs, and the providing of lino for the kitchen and corridor, neither of which were allowed for in the estimate, the total cost will be several hundred dollars under the $3000.00. One delayed invoice is still to be received, which I expect to receive tomorrow, and then the account can be completed, and the returns sent to the Department. The cooperation of the school people, and the free use of their facilities, helped to keep the cost down.

During the past three weeks my small crew and myself have been engaged in building the 20' extension to the school kitchen, as arranged between Bishop Guy and the Department. This work will be completed in another week, after which I will send a brief report on this latter work, and a photo of the annex to the larger building. This work, too, promises to come well within the estimate of $1500.00. I expect to leave for Calgary on Oct. 9th.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

OTTAWA.

Re- Kitchen Extension--St. Bruno School.

Sir:

As indicated in my letter of the 30th ultimo, I now enclose a Statement of Cost of extending the Kitchen at the above school, and photos of the Extension.

The estimated cost of this extension was $1500.00, but as some of the work was done at less than the expected cost, we were able to include a canopy over the large new 3-oven range, and provide AA Battleship Lino for the concrete floor of the extension, and still keep within the estimate. The canopy is vented with a 16" pipe through the ceiling and roof, and will relieve the kitchen of much excess heat, and odours of cooking.

One or two small bills had not been received when I made up the Statement of Cost, but with these added, the total cost will be approximately $1400.00.

The main saving in construction costs was in the concrete cutting, for which I had allowed $198.00 in the Estimate. This wall is splayed, running from 9" on top where it meets the framing, to about 24" on the bottom. I rounded up all the drills on the place, got them sharpened and tempered, and was all set for a tough cutting job, but found the wall to be so full of large round stones with just enough cement to hold them together, that scarcely any actual cutting was necessary. We were able to knock the wall to pieces with sledges, and as the big stones came rolling out most of the concrete came away at the same time. Though not the kind of concrete work that I am accustomed to, yet because of its wide base it is quite equal to carrying the frame superstructure.

With the completion of the kitchen enlargement my duties at St. Bruno School were finished, and I have returned to Calgary. I much appreciate the employment that I have had, and trust it may be my privilege to serve the Department.
further whenever and wherever my services can be utilized.

The Time-Sheets and Invoices have been left with Bishop Guy's Secretary, Rev. A. Charest, and will eventually be forwarded to the Department.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE
PB CALGARY, ALTA., November 13th, 1935.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of St. Bruno's Indian Residential School at Joussard, in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency:

This is a very fine institution: You will recall when you were there they were having difficulty with the floors giving way. Mr. Gardner-Smith was sent from here early in the summer to repair this, and the work has been carried out in a very efficient manner, and I hope we will have no further trouble in this regard.

Everything about the institution, inside and out, was in very good condition. I went over the laundry machinery, boilers, engines, &c., and everything seemed to be in order. The school maintains the services of a lay-brother and an engineer, both of whom are competent in this line of work, and they keep the machinery in a good state of repair.

As you know, the out-buildings at this institution were poor and in a dilapidated condition. I found that a new barn, 50' x 36', was under erection and just nearing completion. This is to be up-to-date in every way, with hay loft, extensions, cement floor, &c. I do not know.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

know whether the Department are paying for this barn, but at any rate it is being erected. No doubt in due course the other out-buildings will all be replaced as well.

The potato crop was not as good as last year on account of the wet weather, and I found this to be the case all over the Peace River country: There was so much rain during the summer that the potatoes rotted in the ground. They had an abundance of other garden truck, however.

I visited the class-rooms and spent some little time with the children, and everything seemed to be going along very well.

The girls receive an exceptionally good training in household science, but here, as in the other two schools in that Agency, the boys receive very little outside training with the exception of doing a few chores, attending to the gardens, milking cows, &c. I find this is being absolutely neglected in most cases, and I believe the time has come when we should check up on this a little more closely. dressed and seemed to be getting sufficient food. The School have 46 head of cattle, of which 25 are cows, and 10 were being milked at the time of my inspection and the milk is all given to the children in one form or another. They also have some pigs and chickens.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 22nd November 1935.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 6th November, 1935, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, representing:

That building operations enumerated hereunder were carried out during the past summer at each of the St. Bernard's, St. Bruno's, Sturgeon Lake and Wabasca Roman Catholic Indian Residential Schools, located in the Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency, northern Alberta;

That as these schools are in an isolated locality, it has been found that the most economical method of arranging for construction is to place the work in charge of the Oblate Order, under whose auspices they are conducted;

That all work was approved by the Department and carried out on a day labour basis, under the direct supervision of His Lordship Right Reverend Joseph Guy, O.M.I., Bishop of Grouard, at a cost of $24,800;

That the cost of the work at each school, including material and labour, was as follows:

St. Bernard's:
- Erection of a new building, to provide classrooms, sewing room, dormitory and laundry ... $16,000

St. Bruno's:
- Repairing foundation, main building - $3,300
- Erecting kitchen - $1,400
- Erecting barn - $1,500 6,200

Sturgeon Lake:
- Miscellaneous repairs, school buildings 500

Wabasca:
- Erecting machine shed and chicken house 2,100

That funds to cover the cost of the above mentioned work are provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, 1935-36.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, advise that authority be granted for the expenditure of the said sum of $24,800 in payment of the cost of the above mentioned work.

The Honourable
The Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I take the liberty of calling your attention on the fact that the batteries at Joussard Residential School are out of commission or will be in the very near future. We are getting very poor light and soon will have none. Said batteries have been well looked after and have been used quite a long time over the regular one they are guaranteed for.

I would therefore ask for a new set of batteries of 56 or rather as was the case in Croward and for the same reason two sets of 56 making a total of 112. I suggest Ironclad Batteries and I am sure I am meeting with the approval of the Department Architect.

Please give that matter your kind and effective attention and oblige.

Very truly yours,

Bishop of Croward.

Dear Bishop Guy,

I have Your Lordship's letter of July 17th and as an explanation of the delay in replying I would say that I have just returned from making official visits to agencies in Manitoba and Western Ontario.

Your letter was marked 'Personal', otherwise it would have been brought to the attention of the Schools Branch, which I am now having done.

Yours faithfully,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Right Reverend Joseph Guy, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Grouard,
Grouard, Alta.
